Liebherr’s core construction crane unit continues to expand globally with forays into Eastern Europe and China this year. Growing business supplying large antifriction bearings and drive systems to wind power companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jet-setting Colombian billionaire is shopping for a buyer for his Bavaria brewery, Latin America’s second-largest. Also controls interests in media, oil and staffing outfits. Last year sold off Avianca Airlines, a perennial moneyloser. (In 1989 a terrorist reportedly blew up one of the airline’s flights after buying a ticket under Santo Domingo’s name.) Keeps homes in New York, Paris and Baru, his private island. Once served as Colombia’s ambassador to China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive twins no more, thanks to their bid for some of the media assets of Conrad Black’s troubled Hollinger International. Despite a long, drawn out trial, at which Frederick testified, brothers successfully acquired the Telegraph Group for $1.2 billion. In past three years have also acquired U.K. retailer Littlewoods and mail-order operations of the GUS group (a major shareholder of Burberry). They manage these businesses along with their extensive real estate portfolio from the island tax haven of Jersey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Metro Cash & Carry in 1964, which eventually developed into Metro AG, now the world’s fifth-largest retailer. Still owns almost 19% of the group. Now retired, runs an Internet and technology company, Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, and has built a 172,000-square-foot luxury development complete with hotels, apartments, office space, restaurants and shops near the Potsdamer Platz in central Berlin. The complex is likely to become embroiled in war restitution claim as a Jewish family has alleged that the land on which it stands was illegally sold to Beisheim. An avid sports fan (golf, tennis), has three foundations that fund athletic programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Norwegian welder turned a ship-brokering job as a teenager into control of the world’s largest fleet of oil tankers, through flagship Frontline Ltd. Benefiting from surging demand from China and India. Made big investment in liquefied natural gas tankers, betting that LNG would become the next crude oil; wager has yet to pay off. In the meantime he is awash in cash from spinoffs of Frontline subsidiaries and investments in overseas shipping companies like General Maritime. Collects classic Norwegian art. Reportedly turned down an offer of $190 million from fellow billionaire Roman Abramovich for his London home last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of Texas oilman Perry Bass (see). Graduated from Yale, Stanford Business School. Father handed family business to eldest son, Sid; Robert, feeling overshadowed, broke out on his own 1983; moved one floor down in Bass-financed Fort Worth office tower. Arguably the better investor: diversified holdings included Wometco, Continental Broadcasting, Lone Star Technologies, San Juan Basin Royalty Trust. Sold Plaza Hotel to Donald Trump. His Oak Hill Capital Partners specializes in leveraged buyouts. Recent deal: buying Duane Reade drugstore for $700 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father’s one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built into Power Corp., a $13 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant. Power Corp. consortium bought an indirect 25% stake in media giant Bertelsmann in early 2001. Also owns Investors Group, Canada’s largest mutual fund group, and has holdings in specialty mineral companies and waste services. The stock, which split in 2004, is up 25% in the past year. While sons Andre and Paul Jr. run the company, Paul Sr. collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. Half-brothers took over 1969, expanded Franklin Resources by adding Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Also bought Heine Securities from value investor Michael Price (see) for $610 million in 1996. Today firm manages more than $350 billion. FKR named after Ben Franklin for his common sense, frugality. Yale grad and former Army lieutenant serves as chairman; son Charles’ son, Gregory, assists as co-CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made telecom entrepreneur. Runs India’s largest GSM-based cellular service provider, Bharti Tele-Ventures, whose stock is up 24% since January. Added 4 million subscribers in the past year, taking total to more than 10 million. Started venture to export fruits and vegetables with the Rothschild family. Spending $4.5 million to provide mobile services in tsunami-hit Andaman & Nicobar islands.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate lawyer joined dad’s Tana Oil & Gas in 1980; sold production units to Texaco in 1989, exploration division to Unocal. Bought luxury hospitality chain Omni Hotels 1996; now 40 hotels throughout North America. New Tana incarnation now producing gas in the Gulf. Branching out: last year bought legendary Gold’s Gym for $158 million and grabbed a stake in fast-growing Mexican dollar-store chain Waldo’s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers own 19% of retailer Metro. Also control the Travel Charm chain of luxury hotels and spas located along Germany’s Baltic coast. In operation since 2000, the chain plans to open its first Austrian hotel later this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though his reality TV show was trumped by the Apprentice master, Branson cashed in on several ventures. Virgin Mobile U.K. went public last year and his Australian airline Virgin Blue went public in December 2003; Virgin Mobile U.S. will likely follow later this year. He’ll need the extra bucks to fund his megavisions: his Airbus’ A380 plane, scheduled for takeoff in the spring of 2008, will provide such amenities as a gym, casino and salon, while his Virgin Galactic will reportedly offer customers trips to outer space in as soon as three years. In the near term trying to fight off hostile takeover bid for Virgin Blue.

name: Billionaires
bio: Army surgical technician became hypodermic-needle salesman, started own medical device company in 1963 from Bloomington apartment. Made wire guides for angioplasty, catheters, stents. Today Cook Group: manufacturer of 30,000 medical devices, estimated $600 million sales. Planned to sell it all to rival Guidant for $3 billion, but deal derailed after disappointing clinical tests of innovative stent. Cook Group moving on: converted old Bloomington RCA television factory into biotech lab. Early-bird worker still arrives every day at 5 a.m., but son, Carl, being groomed to take over company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold most of Banco Real to ABN Amro in 1998 for $2.1 billion. He named the unsold portion Banco Alfa, which has since grown to Brazil’s 16th-largest bank, with $2.7 billion in assets. Also owns the leading home improvement chain in Brazil, Casa e Construcao, in addition to a large palm oil producer, hotels, radio stations and 12,000 acres of farmland.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a few rocky years Gerling Konzern, one of the world’s largest reinsurers, returned to profitability in 2003 just in time for its 100th birthday celebration last May. Small thanks to owner Rolf Gerling, who despite his 94% stake and his training as an economist, pays little attention to the business, preferring to devote all his time to his Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world’s impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Sall (see) owners of SAS Institute, world’s largest privately held software company. Designs advanced statistical-modeling software for pharmaceutical giants such as Merck and Eli Lilly, now trying to attract banks and financial institutions with data-crunching and anti-money-laundering software. Techie employees kept happy with lucrative perks like child-care centers, Olympic-size swimming pool, 35-hour workweek, free soda and candy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision, which manufactures personal computers and PC servers. Spun off its handsetmaking unit Foxconn International Holdings in an offering in February. Foxconn, which now has a market capitalization of approximately $3 billion, plans to spend at least 60% of the proceeds building three new plants in China and expanding others in Mexico and Hungary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of August Kühne, one of the founders of publicly traded transport and logistics group Kühne & Nagel. Has run the company since 1965; holds 56% of the shares. His extravagant house in landlocked Switzerland is said to look like the main command deck of an ocean liner.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Ronald (see), Sons of cosmetics doyenne Estée Lauder, who died in April at age 97. Mother founded company with husband, Joseph, 1946, pushing face cream made by chemist uncle in kitchen; now controls nearly half the premium cosmetics market in U.S. Family sold 13 million shares of stock to meet large estate tax bill after matriarch’s death; Lauders still retain 46% stake in the company, majority of voting shares. Leonard: chairman of company since 1995. Son William, 44, took over CEO spot last July. Ronald: international investor with television properties in eastern Europe, Israel. Served as deputy assistant secretary of defense and ambassador to Austria under President Reagan. Eponymous foundation provides Jewish education throughout eastern and central Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction baron. Inherited from his father but built his own legacy by taking on construction contracts abroad starting with Oman, where he built the sultan’s palace. Now building Mumbai’s tallest buildings, two 60-story apartment towers. But his most valuable asset these days is his 18.4% stake in Tata Sons; its software arm Tata Consultancy Services listed last year and now has a market cap of approximately $15 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate mogul owns and operates 17.9 million square feet of floor space mainly in Tokyo’s choicest districts. Mori Trust posted a record high $1.2 billion in sales and $150 million in profits for last year (ended Mar. 31). That should give him confidence as he has announced plans to list Mori Trust on the Tokyo stock exchange. Akira’s ongoing sibling rivalry with older brother Minoru is often the subject of media ribbing. Press accounts refer to Mori as “a flinty businessman.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened stock market to the masses with eponymous discount brokerage founded in 1971. Tapped into 1990s online trading boom, only to see much of business dry up with the market. Handed over CEO duties in 2003, took them back last year after company posted sagging profits; stock rallied 7% day after announcement. Dyslexic, established Charles and Helen Schwab Foundation to help children with learning disabilities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left Washington University and landed in Navy, became fighter pilot on U.S.S. Enterprise during World War II. Sold cars after war, became regional Cadillac distributor. Took 50% pay cut to start own car-leasing business with boss; offered rentals as temporary replacements for stolen, wrecked cars. Business boomed in 1970s after courts made insurance companies pay for replacement rentals. Emphasizes training, motivation of employees. Son Andrew began working for father “as soon as I could drive”; now president of car rental giant.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former physicist, cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues. In 1995 set aside 7% of his SAP shares (now worth more than $3 billion) for a foundation now housed in the Villa Bosch, former home of German Nobel Prize-winning chemist, Carl Bosch. Amateur astronomer, has a small planet between Mars and Jupiter named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief of Fast Retailing, which owns the Uniqlo casual clothing chain, Japan’s version of the Gap. For fiscal 2004, ended August 31, profits jumped 54% to $611 million with a women&#39s clothing line luring back customers. Last year Uniqlo opened 78 new outlets, and its U.K. store posted its first profit since opening in 2001. The company plans to open its first store in South Korea this fall. That business will be run in conjunction with Lotte Shopping, a subsidiary of Korean billionaire Shin Kyuk-Ho.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Jerry Yang, erstwhile Internet darlings must feel a bit nostalgic, watching all the hoopla over Google’s young Turks. Thirtysomethings met as grad students at Stanford in 1989, developed Internet search portal. Became Internet billionaires taking Yahoo public in 1996. Survivor of the dot-com meltdown now profitable, but may well regret making a $10 million investment in rival Google 5 years ago, despite the spectacular 5,000% return. Yahoo stopped using Google technology to run searches in February 2004, now feverishly developing competing engine of its own. Partners retain Chief Yahoo title, but this business now run by former Warner Bros. chief Terry Semel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hers is a modern-day fairy tale: Heidi Jelinek, then about 19, met Helmut Horten, founder of the eponymous German department store chain, in 1959 in a hotel bar. Despite a 30-year age difference they married seven years later. When he died in 1987, he left her a $1 billion fortune. The merry widow now divides her time between a penthouse in Vienna, a home in Lyford Cay and houses in the Tessin and by the Wörthersee in Austria. Owns one of the world’s largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII.

name: Billionaires
bio: The ultraprivate Israeli brothers boast a vast portfolio of shipping and real estate assets. (Monaco-based Sammy handles the shipping, while the real estate is tended to by Yuli from Tel Aviv.) Last year media criticized Sammy’s sale of 12 container ships to Zim Navigation, a company he controls, for $820 million. In partnership with Chicago’s Pritzker family, the Ofer brothers also control a $1.5 billion stake in cruise giant Royal Caribbean. As part of their planning for the next generation, the brothers announced last year that they would formally split their holdings, and would ultimately be succeeded by their children. Sammy, an avid art collector, boasts one of the world’s largest collections of original Marc Chagall paintings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout borrowed $5,000 from aunt to set up first shop specializing in women’s sportswear in 1963. Took company public 1969. Expanded Limited Brands into 3,800 stores and 7 retail brands, including Victoria’s Secret, Express, Henri Bendel. Also Bath & Body Works, White Barn Candle Co. Established the Wexner Foundation in 1984 to support Jewish studies.

name: Billionaires
bio: With late partner Jay Van Andel, high school friends started out in 1950s selling nutritional supplements, turned Amway into direct-selling empire with more than 3 million people worldwide pushing personal- care and home products. Reorganized under Alticor banner; second generation now at the helm. Annual sales approach $5 billion, much of it from overseas operations. Families remain close, both major civic donors in Grand Rapids, Mich. DeVos owns pro basketball’s Orlando Magic, recently donated $1 million to hurricane relief.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gates is far richer, but Jobs is way cooler with the kids. For that he can thank two decades of innovative design and catchy marketing. And now iPod, portable music player (more than 3 million units sold since 2001), helped make Apple's iTunes Music Store the dominant site for downloading music: over 125 million downloads, accounting for 70% of all (legal) Internet music sales. Result: Apple stock up more than 200% in the past year. Personal wealth lies elsewhere, in digital animation shop Pixar (Toy Story, Finding Nemo). The hot studio still hasn't found a new home after severing its relationship with Disney last year, culminating a feud between Jobs and alpha-mouse Michael Eisner.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Ann inherited big Wal-Mart stake from father, James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail chain with brother Sam. Husband, E. Stanley Kroenke
(see), a real estate developer, including shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Also owns more than 1 million acres of ranch land. Sports nut Stan owns stake in pro football’s St. Louis Rams, basketball’s Denver Nuggets and hockey’s Colorado Avalanche.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star Wars mastermind putting finishing touches on the final installment of his 6-part space epic—Episode III: The Revenge of the Sith, set for release in May. Also runs special-effects shop Industrial Light & Magic (Harry Potter movies, Master and Commander). Possible future projects: sequels to Jurassic Park, Indiana Jones.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $3 billion (sales) tour outfit Globus & Cosmos was founded in 1928 by father, Antonio, with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. President Sergio has been with the company for 50 years. Loves expensive toys: has a helicopter and a yacht (Lady Marina) and a $600,000 Mercedes Maybach. Son Fabio is CEO of Monarch Travel, the family’s no-frills airline. Son Paolo, who was CEO of Globus’ American arm, Group Voyagers, committed suicide last year at age 34.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of company founder Mario Prada runs the $1.7 billion (2003 sales) luxury-goods maker with husband, Patrizio Bertelli. She is lead designer; he is chief executive. Openly admits to combative professional-personal marriage. Struggles lie ahead: how to proceed with the Prada-owned Helmut Lang and Jil Sander brands now that both designers resigned amidst squabbles over creative and financial direction. Plans to go public have been postponed three times and are now on hold until, possibly, 2006. Today Prada boasts 210 stores worldwide, including 10 new ones in China. Holds a Ph.D. in political science and was, for a time, a mime artist, feminist and communist. For the past decade the couple has been hosting shows of internationally recognized contemporary artists through their foundation; it brought the Tribeca Film Festival to Milan in 2004.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: Butcher’s apprentice turned drugstore king. Owns 73% of Germany’s drugstores, with 13,300 locations. Runs the $8.4 billion (sales) company with help from wife, Christa, and sons Lars and Meike. Expanding into new markets including Denmark, Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Spain, France and Italy. A penny-pincher, reportedly pays new employees lower-than-promised salaries. Enjoys football and sport cars (supposedly owns a Ferrari, an Aston Martin, a Porsche and Jaguar).

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a fried-mussel-pancake street vendor in Bangkok is now Thailand’s richest businessperson thanks to his near monopoly on whisky. A decade ago he jumped into the beer business and chipped away at rival Singha’s dominating market share. Now he’s ready to take his alcohol empire public in an offering expected to take place by this summer. Plans to use the proceeds to introduce his beer brand in Thai restaurants around the world. He has already started promoting himself abroad, becoming the official sponsor of Liverpool’s Everton soccer club last year. The billionaire’s hotel collection includes the Plaza Athénée in New York and Bangkok.

name: Billionaires
bio: Honorary chairman of Ito-Yokado, one of Japan’s major retail chains. Included in the company’s massive portfolio: 10,615 Seven-Eleven stores in Japan (the country&#39s largest retailer), 181 Ito-Yokado superstores, and 584 Denny&#39s restaurants. After fighting in WWII, 21-year-old Masatoshi joined his mother and brother in running a small clothing shop in Tokyo. Ito became a convert of Sears-style self-service retailing following a visit to the U.S. in 1961. He returned home to convert his shop into a superstore (food, clothing, and household products) and expanded the chain operation in Tokyo. His rise isn’t completely without blemish. In 1992 an Ito employee was found to have paid protection money to local mobsters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Native Pole, former chambermaid married John Seward Johnson (d. 1983), son of founder of Johnson & Johnson. Inherited large stake in J&J. Converted New Jersey mansion into tournament-quality golf club, but “Basia” now based in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Electronics salesman started own car-stereo shop in 1966. Added appliances, VCRs to bring in older customers; changed name to Best Buy. Introduced big-box store concept: stacked inventory on sales floor, let customers fiddle with products. Today 750 stores, $25 billion in sales. Stepped down as CEO in 2002. Established the Schulze School of Entrepreneurship at University of St. Thomas (Minnesota) in August.

name: Billionaires
bio: Following the Tsai brothers’ decision to split the family’s financial group back in the late 1980s, Tsai Wan Tsai took over Fubon Financial Holdings. He has since passed the reins on to his sons, Daniel, a Georgetown law graduate, and Richard, who earned an M.B.A. from New York University’s Stern school. Last year Citigroup cashed in most of its 10% stake in Fubon, about 600 million shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former jazz pianist (stage name: Charlie Walker) sold his retail chain, Billa in 1996. Invested proceeds in prime Austrian real estate like the Radisson and Europa hotels in Salzburg; the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange; the Hotel Lasalle and four palaces in Vienna. Now one of the country’s largest private real estate owners. The city of Vienna has awarded him a gold medal for his support of the city and his generous donations to the city hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Bronfman clan continues to press on, hoping music will cure its recent Vivendi-induced hangover. In November 2003 nephew Edgar Jr., along with LBO titan Thomas Lee, bought Warner Music Group for $2.6 billion, just months after failed attempt to buy back Vivendi assets. Public offering rumored to be already in the works. Father Samuel made fortune selling Seagram’s Canadian whiskey in the U.S. during Prohibition. Brother Edgar took over spirits business in 1971, turning it into a well-respected, diversified conglomerate. Nephew Edgar Jr., later put in charge; who went Hollywood. Unloaded DuPont stake for shares of Time Warner; sold Tropicana juice business to finance purchase of MCA/Universal. Sour mix: with box office sales flat and music business in disarray, sold everything to Vivendi for $34 billion in 2000. After helping oust Vivendi chief Jean-Marie Messier in 2002, Charles cut his losses. Vivendi stake believed to be worth only $500 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Pittsburgh steel mogul John Hartwell Hillman Jr., industrialist who built Pittsburgh Coke & Chemical. Henry earned geology degree from Princeton, joined father’s company, took control in 1959. Changed focus of investments from smokestack industries to real estate, venture capital. Early backer of tech prodigy Kleiner Perkins and buyout kings Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bronx-born son of Russian immigrants dropped out of college, became clerk at Brooks Brothers. Designed ties for Beau Brummel before launching Polo in 1967 with $50,000. Built Polo empire: men’s and women’s clothing, kids’ gear, luggage, fabrics, fragrances, house paint, furniture. Sold 28% of company to Goldman Sachs for $138 million in 1994; took public 1997. Racing car and motorcycle collector; owns homes in Colorado, Jamaica and New York. Eldest son, Andrew, a producer. Daughter, Dylan, runs Manhattan candy store. Youngest son, David, Polo senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation of a Swiss-German industrial fortune. Sold his stake of the family business to brother Thomas in the late-1980s. Has used proceeds to invest in a range of industries from gypsum products, packaging materials, real estate, steel production and watches, including the precursor of Swatch. In 2003 retired from all corporate and board responsibilities to focus full-time on philanthropy. Donated more than $1 billion worth of shares of South American wood products and water pipeline manufacturer GrupoNueva to the Viva Trust, his foundation which runs Avina, grantmaker for educational, social and environmental projects in Latin America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Electrical engineering degree from Princeton; doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley. Conducted computer-science research at famed Bell Labs and Xerox Palo Alto Research Center (PARC). Jumped to pre-IPO Sun Microsystems in 1983; led development of its Java code technology. Left to run Novell, fled flailing software outfit for fledgling Internet search engine Google; named chief executive August 2001. Became a billionaire after Google IPO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads a diversified empire in Mexico that includes one of the world’s biggest silver producers, owned by his Industrias Peñoles; the successful department store Palacio de Hierro (likened to the Bergdorf Goodman of Mexico); and a major insurance company. Sits on the board of Femsa, Mexico’s largest beverage bottling company. Passionate about bullfighting and horse racing, Bailleres is said to own a ranch where bulls are raised. Also reportedly owns a yacht, called the Mayan Queen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Seagram spirits empire from father, Sam, Russian émigré who founded Distillers Corp. in Montreal in 1924, made millions running whiskey across U.S.-Canadian border during Prohibition. Edgar expanded with Chivas Regal, Absolut Vodka, Tropicana, big stake in DuPont. Son Edgar Jr. unloaded juice and nylon interests to finance Hollywood binge: 15% of Time Warner, $5.7 billion purchase of MCA/Universal. Sold everything to French conglomerate Vivendi in 2000 for $34 billion in stock, then watched fortune plummet. Attempt to buy back assets failed; Edgar Jr. teamed up with Tom Lee (see) in $2.6 billion buy of Warner Music (Madonna, Metallica). Edgar Sr. still active in Jewish causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: An upscale U.K. landowner, Cadogan is actively revamping his Chelsea commercial portfolio to attract higher-end office tenants (including European venture capitalists Nylon Capital and Crescent Capital) and retail tenants (like Chloe, a tony French designer; Bulgari, the Italian jeweler; and Jo Malone, the perfume store where Madonna buys her scents). In July 2004 completed his four-year project to convert a former Chelsea church into a concert hall. The new Cadogan Hall, permanent home of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra, has since opened to rave reviews.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father’s dust-removal business into GEA, a thermal-engineering firm. In 1999 sold his stake to MG Technologies for a 21% stake in the combined group and $1 billion in cash. Settled in Switzerland where he runs Luserve AG, a financial consulting firm. Married, with six children, he has a foundation that supports projects in Third World countries and reportedly owns a luxury resort, Fregate Island, in the Seychelles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former exec at real estate syndicate Property Research started storage business 1972; merged with Storage Equities, took public 1995. Today one of nation’s largest self-storage companies: 800,000 self-storage spaces in 80 cities. Also rents 10 million square feet of commercial real estate through PS Business Parks. Stepped down as CEO in 2002; remains chairman. Donated $200 million Parker Hughes Cancer Center in St. Paul, Minn., named for his late son.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Leonard (see), sons of cosmetics doyenne Estée Lauder, who died in April at age 97. Mother founded company with husband, Joseph, 1946, pushing face cream made by chemist uncle in kitchen; now controls nearly half the premium cosmetics market in U.S. Family sold 13 million shares of stock to meet large estate tax bill after matriarch’s death; Lauders still retain 46% stake in the company, majority of voting shares. Leonard: chairman of company since 1995. Son William, 44, took over CEO spot last year. Ronald: international investor with television properties in eastern Europe, Israel. Served as deputy assistant secretary of defense and ambassador to Austria under President Reagan. Eponymous foundation provides Jewish education throughout eastern and central Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Booming global paper industry helped double profits at pulp manufacturer CMPC, the Matte family’s largest holding. The family announced plans to spend $1 billion on new pulp-processing plants and mills in 2005 in hopes of claiming more of the global market. Also boasts interests in Chilean banks, real estate and shipping ports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formerly Bogotá’s top builder, Sarmiento now concentrates on Grupo Aval, his profitable network of regional banks. Retreats to Cotton Bay Club, his private island in the Bahamas. President Alvaro Uribe recently inducted Sarmiento into the Order of Boyaca, one of Colombia’s highest civilian honors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood’s most revered director/producer, also one of its richest. And getting richer: DreamWorks took public its hot animation unit last year. With David Geffen, Jeffrey Katzenberg (see both), launched DreamWorks with grand plans for multifaceted entertainment giant, but subsequently scaled back. Spielberg put up $33 million for 22% of upstart studio in 1994. “My head’s not in the clouds, but I think I’ve gotten too much credit for being an astute businessman.” Arizona-raised movie buff rejected by top film schools, then dropped out of Cal State Long Beach (he eventually returned and earned a degree). Broke into entertainment as a TV director for Universal, directed his first movie, Duel, in 1971, but it only reached TV screens in the U.S. His third film, Jaws (1975), set the template for the modern blockbuster. Built much of his fortune by directing or producing: Raiders of the Lost Ark, E.T., Jurassic Park, Schindler’s List, Men in Black, among others. Next up: reteaming with Tom Cruise (they did Minority Report) for remake of H.G. Wells’ War of the Worlds.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $2.5 billion (revenues) Hubert Burda Media Holding publishes 250 titles including Focus, Bunte and Freundin. Newer titles include Elle Girl, Frau im Trend and Young. Keeps a high profile, appearing at such events as the Bambi prize (Germany’s academy awards) and hobnobbing at the World Economic Forum at Davos. To celebrate his 65th birthday in February 2005, donated $1.3 million to the Jewish Center in Munich to support a new synagogue, museum and cultural center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband, Bronson Ingram, inherited father’s oil-and-barge empire in 1963. Expanded with distribution business: books, computers, videotapes. Started computer wholesale distributor Ingram Micro. Martha, director of public affairs at Ingram from 1979. Sold off oil and gas businesses, took Ingram Micro public. Chairman after Bronson’s death in 1995, spun off Ingram Entertainment to son David in 1997. Presides as chairman of Ingram Industries, but parceled out the divisions to other children: son John runs Ingram Book division, wholesale distributor of books and audiotapes to retailers and libraries. Son Orrin runs boat division: 4,000 barges, hundreds of tugboats along major rivers, intercoastal waterways. Martha also board member of Weyerhaeuser and AmSouth BankCorp; active in Nashville philanthropic, social circuit.

name: Billionaires
bio: This metals magnate is known in Russia as “the unseen man” because of his low profile. Founded Rossiysky Kredit, one of Russia’s largest banks until the ruble devaluation of August 1998. He used the bank in 1993 to purchase a 20% stake in the Mikhailovsky iron ore and processing facility at a privatization auction, later purchasing more shares from managers and workers. At the end of last year sold Mikhailovsky, the second-largest such manufacturer in Russia, to fellow billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Vasily Anisimov.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. Half-brothers took over 1969, expanded Franklin Resources by adding Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Also bought Heine Securities from value investor Michael Price (see) for $610 million in 1996. Today firm manages $353 billion. FKR named after Ben Franklin for his common sense, frugality. Last year company suspended 3 employees following federal investigation into alleged-market timing. Washington & Lee grad and former marine serves as vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made billionaire chairs Dallah Albaraka, a banking and media empire. Has announced plans for a $2 billion (assets) Islamic bank based in Bahrain. Some say it is a pipe dream and may go the way of his floundering media assets. Kamel was investigated in the U.S. for allegedly helping bankroll Osama bin Laden; last September, Cantor Fitzgerald named him in a Sept. 11th-related lawsuit. Kamel denies all allegations and is working to clear his name.

name: Billionaires
bio: This former tennis-player-turned-investment-banker owes most of his fortune to beer. Last year Interbrew of the Netherlands merged with Brazilian brewer AmBev, in which Lemann had an 8% stake. His share of the newly named InBev helped double his fortune from a year ago. Reportedly lives in Geneva, Switzerland following a kidnapping attempt on his children some years ago. His Fundaçao Lemann (Lemann Foundation) focuses on improving education in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: The largest diamond cutter and polisher in the world. Last year turned his attention to real estate, buying property in Moscow, Las Vegas, Miami and New York—including the famed Chase Manhattan building, which he plans to convert into luxury apartments. Born in Uzbekistan; his Lubavitcher-Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. Made his name undercutting De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. Reportedly pocketed millions helping oligarchs sell some of Russia’s $12 billion in diamond reserves following fall of the Iron Curtain. His Group also includes swimsuitmaker Gottex, 1,700 Fina gas stations in the Southwest U.S. and a stake in Israel’s first toll road. A devout Jew, donates at least $30 million annually to the Chabad movement, which seeks to return lost Jews to the flock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Paintball enthusiast who was the subject of scandal in January. The SEC accused Salinas of failing to disclose certain debt transactions as part of a scheme “to reap a tremendous personal profit at the expense of investors;” the SEC said Salinas bought the discounted debt of one of his companies’ subsidiaries and then sold it back to the company, TV Azteca, at face value, pocketing close to $109 million in the process for himself and a partner. Fiery-tongued Salinas responded to the accusation defiantly, insisting that the move benefited his shareholders: “The SEC accusations are false, in bad faith and discriminatory. We will prevail because we acted correctly... It is these irresponsible and arbitrary SEC actions, not the debt transactions, which are adversely affecting both minority and majority shareholders.” The case is pending. Salinas also owns most of the Mexican retailer and consumer bank Grupo Elektra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Transformed Keyence Corp. from a small sensor-making outfit based in a seedy area of Western Japan with just 3 employees into a sensor giant with $1.1 billion in sales last year. Today Keyence manufactures laser, fiber-optic and pressure sensors, bar code readers, detection control devices and color vision systems. Greater overseas demand boosted profits by 48% last year to $335 million. Takizaki wants to increase the overseas sales ratio to 50% from its current 20%. That’s all he’ll fess to—media-shy Takizaki refuses to discuss anything non-business related, including family and hobbies.

name: Billionaires
bio:
America’s love affair with The Donald reaching impossibly new highs: his reality show, The Apprentice, was prime-time television’s highest-rated series last year. His Visa commercials air around the clock. His casinos, well, his detractors can point to them and say, “You’re fired.” After nearly defaulting on its debt obligations, Trump’s gaming properties to reorganize; Trump to relinquish controlling stake, role as chief executive (still retains chairman title). No matter. For Donald, real estate is where his real wealth lies. Over 18 million square feet of prime Manhattan space, including 
40 Wall Street, Trump World Tower, Trump International Hotel & Tower. Complicated partnerships make ascertaining net worth difficult, but there’s no confusing the success of West Side rail yard residential development: 80-acre parcel bought for $80 million in 1985 now fetching more than $2,000 per square foot. Avid golfer set to open new 18-hole golf course in Bedminster, N.J.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner David Filo, erstwhile Internet darlings must feel a bit nostalgic, watching all the hoopla over Google’s young Turks. Thirtysomethings met as grad students at Stanford in 1989, developed Internet search portal. Became Internet billionaires taking Yahoo public in 1996. Survivor of the dot-com meltdown now profitable, but may well regret making a $10 million investment in rival Google 5 years ago, despite the spectacular 5,000% return. Yahoo stopped using Google technology to run searches in February 2004, now feverishly developing competing engine of its own. Partners retain Chief Yahoo title, but this business now run by former Warner Bros. chief Terry Semel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Ethiopia and now a Saudi citizen, Al Amoudi made his fortune in construction and real estate before expanding into oil refineries in Sweden and Morocco. Now he’s plowing refinery profits into his native Ethiopia buying assets and bankrolling the national soccer team. His Sheraton Addis Ababa Hotel, which hosted U2 front man Bono when he toured Africa, faces new competition from Saudi Arabia’s richest man, Prince Alwaleed Bin Talal, who is negotiating to buy the once-grand Ghion Hotel, built by the late Ethiopian emperor Haile Selassie.

name: Billionaires
bio: Though he sold his stock in 1996, this heir to the Campbell Soup fortune remains on of the richest men in Ireland, where he fled from the US in 1994 to avoid taxes.  Dorrance lives a quiet life and keeps clear of the press, resurfacing in the early 1990s to pressure Wyoming legislators to legalize game ranching for native and exotic wildlife.  The bid failed, along with his plans to raise imported sheep, boar, elk and wolf.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Grupo Votorantim, one of Brazil’s largest family-owned conglomerates, operating in aluminum, pulp & paper, cement and orange juice, with $6.1 billion in revenue in 2004. Votorantim expanded its presence in the U.S. earlier this year with acquisitions of cement plants in the Great Lakes region. Antonio and his family share ownership in the group with three other siblings and their descendants. As part of a move to professionalize, members of the Ermirio de Moraes family handed over operational duties several years ago and formed an executive committee.

name: Billionaires
bio: n the 1960s she and younger sister Alicia inherited construction giant Fomentos de Construcciones y Contratas, the company their father founded in 1944. In 1997 bought out Alicia for $800 million. Recently upped her stake to 38.5%, in a bid to tighten her control on the group after a rival had tried to buy up shares. A member of Spanish nobility, she was awarded last year’s Montblanc prize given to the best woman chief executive of the year. Her three daughters, Esther, Alicia and Carmen, now sit on FCC’s supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last October Kristiansen stepped down as chief executive of Lego, the ailing Danish toy company founded by his grandfather in 1932. Losses on the order of $35 million are expected for 2004, marking the fourth year in seven that the $1.5 billion (sales) company has operated in the red. Blame diminished demand. There are plans to sell of Lego’s  trademark theme parks, though it’s unclear how many or when. Currently ranked sixth on Young & Rubicam’s list of the world’s best-known brands for families—which includes giants Disney and Coca Cola—Lego executives reportedly are aiming to make the top five this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hard-nosed chairman of ESL Investments made headlines in November with the merger of Kmart and Sears Roebuck & Co.; deal caps one of the greatest corporate comebacks in history for Kmart. ESL rebounded in 2003: $6 billion fund reportedly up at least 20% after falling 15% in 2002. Since founding investment firm in 1988, annual returns averaging 25%. Risk taker also has large stake in AutoZone. Got start with summer job at Goldman Sachs. Protégé of Robert Rubin; got an early investment from Richard Rainwater (see). High-profile client roster, including Michael Dell, David Geffen, Tisch family’s Loews Corp.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, and his brother, Sam Walton, ran a handful of small five-and-dime stores in Missouri; with Sam, built the first Wal-Mart in Rogers, Ark. in 1962. Nancy inherited large Wal-Mart stake after Bud’s death in 1995. Established, serves as president of New York City’s Cedar Lake Ensemble, also Missouri’s Columbia Performing Arts Centre: dance instruction school enrolls nearly 600 students per year. With husband, Bill, owns pro hockey’s St. Louis Blues. Big givers to Missouri-area hospitals, young women’s causes. Donated $25 million to University of Missouri for new basketball arena named after daughter, Paige.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of John D. Rockefeller, grain merchant who turned a $4,000 investment into Standard Oil. Dominated oil market until federal regulators forced its breakup in landmark 1911 antitrust case. David’s father, John D. Rockefeller Jr., moved money into real estate (Rockefeller Center) and philanthropy (Rockefeller University). Sibling Laurance Rockefeller, staunch environmentalist instrumental in fostering national park system, died at age 94 in July; David now the sole survivor of his generation. Still active: with daughter recently opened Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture, nonprofit organic farm dedicated to sustainable agriculture, with high-end restaurant and cafe, built on family’s 4,000-acre Pocantico estate north of New York City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Generic drug czar became the scourge of big pharma by relentlessly litigating drug exclusivity patents in the courts. Founded Apotex in 1974 and grew it into Canada's largest drugmaker. His Barr Laboratories is still waiting for the FDA to rule on over-the-counter status for its morning-after pill. Inching toward full retirement, Sherman has been gradually selling off his public holdings..

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive hedge fund manager more interested in science than finance; started career as a theoretical mathematician. MIT grad taught at alma mater and Harvard. Broke codes for U.S. Department of Defense. Left in 1968 to take job heading math department at SUNY Stony Brook. Coauthored Cherns-Simons theory 1974, geometry-based formula now used by physicists searching for fundamental laws of the universe. Started investing with $5,000 in wedding presents; bored by stocks, traded soybean futures. Founded Renaissance Technologies hedge fund outfit 1982, generated stellar returns using computer modeling to find inefficiencies in commodities and futures prices. Between 1988 and 1999 his Medallion fund believed to have gained 2,500%. Prefers Ph.D.s to M.B.A.s: “We don’t hire people from Wall Street. We hire people who have done good science.” Also employs computational linguists to analyze markets. Geeky market-modelers kept happy with lax dress code, gym, cash bonuses every 6 months.  Simons believed to own half of Medallion’s $5 billion assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of German bird salesman looking to restore family’s reputation after son Edward, head of Canary Capital hedge fund, set off last fall’s mutual fund scandal with improper market-timing trading scheme. Ed cooperated with authorities, paid $40 million fine. Leonard got start running father’s Hartz pet supply business, made industry leader. Sold 85% of company for $208 million in 2000; also sold Village Voice newspaper. Son Emanuel manages family’s vast real estate empire: 35 million square feet of commercial space in New Jersey, New York City’s posh Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand hotels. Ponied up $30 million in 1988 to get his name on alma mater New York University’s business school. Cofounder of Homes for the Homeless in New York City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esprit’s American founders Douglas and Susie Tompkins gave Ying his big break when they hired him as Esprit’s primary sourcing agent in 1971; later he set up the company’s Asian distributorship, Esprit Far East, which listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange in 1993. Later bought back rights to the brand in the U.S.  Ying stepped aside in 2003 but remains chairman. So far so good, as Esprit’s share price has skyrocketed and Ying has steadily reduced his majority stake down to 22%, pocketing nearly $1 billion along the way.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a coal miner, Akhmetov built his Ukrainian coal and steel empire in the mid-1990s by forging ties with Viktor Yanukovych, then the governor of eastern Ukraine’s coal and steel rich region of Donbas, later prime minister and losing 2004 presidential candidate. With fellow billionaire Viktor Pinchuk won a controversial $800 million bid in 2004 for Ukraine’s largest steel company, Kryvorizhstal. A Kiev court has ruled the sale illegal, but the two are appealing. With his political allies out of favor, reclusive Akhmetov has receded further into the shadows.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father Stephen, co-owners of engineering giant Bechtel. Rebuilding Iraq helped boost engineering giant’s revenues, but bigger business came from $5 billion waste treatment plant in Washington State, $4.5 billion petrochemical complex in southern China. Fourth-generation family business built Hoover Dam, Hong Kong airport, Channel Tunnel, managed Boston’s Big Dig. Family also major stakeholder in private equity investor Fremont Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With son Riley (see), co-owner of engineering giant Bechtel Group. Rebuilding Iraq helped boost engineering giant’s revenues, but bigger business came from $5 billion waste treatment plant in Washington State, $4.5 billion petrochemical complex in southern China. Fourth-generation family business built Hoover Dam, Hong Kong airport, Channel Tunnel, managed Boston’s Big Dig. Family also major stakeholder in private equity investor Fremont Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Immigrated to the U.S. from Russia at age 21 with family; worked way through college. Founded private equity firm Access Industries 1986. Four years later formed investment shop Renova with school friend Viktor Vekselberg; acquired stakes in newly privatized Russian companies. Established informal 3-way partnership among Access, Renova and Alfa Group, run by Russian billionaire Mikhail Fridman. Trio, under AAR moniker, owned controlling stake in Tyumen Oil Company; formed TNK-BP, Russia’s third-largest oil company, in joint deal with British Petroleum. Other investments include controlling stake in Siberian-Urals Aluminum, coal mines, real estate, power company in Kazakhstan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Bouygues, a diversified industrial group founded by his father in 1952, with interests in telecom, media, construction, and utilities. Owns $2.9 billion stake in TF1, the top-rated television channel in France. His company supports charities like the French Association for Spinal Cord research, Mother and Child Hospital in Kabul and Toulouse Midi-Pyrenees Association of guide dogs for the blind.

name: Billionaires
bio: Winner of a protracted family feud. Succeeded in buying out his brother Günter and sister Daniela in mid-2003 after disagreeing with them over management of family’s holding company. With brother Wolfgang, now controls $4.2 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, whose coffee brand is as well-known in Germany as Maxwell House is in the U.S. The holding also controls 50% of Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea products. Now apparently fighting with another sibling, Joachim, who claims his two brothers recently kicked him off the holding’s supervisory board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Has big stake in Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp., one of the city-state’s leading banks. Family’s original fortune came from rubber plantations and the land holdings under them. But they are moving away from that legacy. Last year the family announced plans to close a 60-year-old rubber factory in Malaysia. Well-known philanthropist, through the family’s Lee Foundation, gives away millions to schools, scholarships and other projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Arthur Blank (see), fired from now-defunct Handy Dan Home Improvement Centers in 1978, founded do-it-yourself category killer Home Depot. Took public 3 years later. Founders have hung up their tool belts but remain active: Marcus financing $200 million aquarium in Atlanta; Blank bought football’s Atlanta Falcons in 2002 for $545 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: UCLA grad became talent agent for MCA. Created Embassy Communications with Norman Lear (All in the Family); sold programming interests to Coca-Cola for $485 million. With partners spent $550 million for Spanish-language television broadcaster Univision in 1992; paid $3.5 billion for radio giant Hispanic Broadcasting in 2003. “Jerry” is a big donor to both parties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a small-time trader of watches, Teh had dreams of becoming a lawyer. But too poor to afford it, he instead got a job as a bank clerk in his native Singapore. After work he would take classes in accounting and other banking subjects. In 1966 he founded Public Bank, using profits made from a small real estate deal and money from several investors as seed capital. Today he still runs the bank, now one of the biggest and most respected in Malaysia. (Its symbol is the Bougainvillaea flower, picked in part because it is a hardy flowering plant which survives under conditions of stress.) Loves photography; avid reader. Shuns nepotism: has forbidden his children to work at the bank.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Hungarian immigrant’s family fled Soviet occupation in 1958. Studied economics at UCLA but got hooked on flying. Teamed up with Louis and Leslie Gonda (see both) with the idea of buying, leasing planes to airlines. Sold company in 1990 to American International Group for stock. Art collector and licensed commercial jet pilot financed the $311 million Steven Udvar-Hazy Center of the 
National Air & Space Museum, featuring 181 aircraft and space artifacts.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former plastics engineer, transformed his municipal Committee for Science & Technology into a commercial enterprise, gained access to lucrative government contracts, real estate and capital. His empire, AFK Sistema ("The System"), now consists of some 200 companies with holdings ranging from microchips to toy stores. Company recently listed on the London Stock Exchange. Most valuable is 50% stake in MTS, Russia's largest cellular company. Denies that his company was started with municipal government financial aid; insists he accumulated his first capital exporting oil, importing electronics and food products in early 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Russia’s wealthiest industrialists was largely unknown until five years ago. Abramov finished at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology in 1982. Established a precursor to his EvrazHolding in 1992; made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After Russia’s financial collapse in 1998 he bought up steel companies and coal mines on the cheap and a big stake in Russia’s electric monopoly. Owns the large port of Nakhhodka in Russia’s Far East. Last year he traveled to China with Putin to expand his relationship with that steel-hungry market.

name: Billionaires
bio: After studying oil engineering in college, Bogdanov began his career as an assistant driller and at age 33 was named general director of Surgutneftegaz—now Russia’s third-largest private oil company. During the privatization auctions of the 1990s he grabbed control of the firm for himself and fellow managers. Despite that, he’s known in Russia as a competent, hard-working and honest industrial tycoon. Many regard Surgutneftegaz as the best-managed oil company in Russia, though minority investors grumble at the company’s paltry dividends and primitive accounting. Bogdanov rarely leaves his remote oil town, avoiding press attention and the trappings of wealth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bag boy founded investment company Yucaipa 1986; made fortune with leveraged buyouts of supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen’s, Ralph’s. Los Angeles-based Burkle also on the boards of California companies Yahoo, K&B Homes. Last year sold majority stake in food supplier Golden State Foods to St. Louis-based Wetterau Associates for $110 million. Invested $100 million in Sean (P. Diddy) Combs’ Sean John clothing line in 2003. Late last year merged Alliance Entertainment with publicly-traded Source Interlink; controls majority stake in the $1.5 billion sales outfit. Longtime Democratic fundraiser a close friend, travel partner of Clinton; former President calls Burkle’s 757 private jet “Ron Air.” Other friends: Chris Tucker, Jesse Jackson, Steve Bing. Now suing one-time friend and former Disney exec Michael Ovitz over investments Burkle made in Checkout.com and Talkcity.com during the late 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-record-label tycoon maintains a low, warm profile in the Cayman Islands with proceeds from the $2.7 billion he got from BMG for his Zomba Recordings. But gossips speculate that he won’t stay out of the picture forever. Raised in a middle-class neighborhood in Johannesburg, Calder started out playing bass guitar in local bands, then worked as a scout for EMI Records. Formed Zomba in 1971, emigrated to London four years later, the U.S. in 1978. Pop phenoms Britney Spears, ’N Sync and the Backstreet Boys all recorded their bubblegum pop for his label.

name: Billionaires
bio: Funai Electric makes cheap audiovisual appliances, such as the DVD players that crowd Wal-Mart shelves. Bullish sales of office devices, especially dual deck VCR/DVD players, drove company profits up 36% to $250 million last year. Funai has of late been shifting its company focus to digital devices, including digital cameras and DVD recorders. And the company is paying particular attention to demand for LCD TVs—analysts expect demand to increase by sevenfold by 2009. No wonder Funai is planning to beef up its production rate1000%  over the next five years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of one of the world’s largest temp agencies returns to FORBES billionaires list for the first time in five years. Holds 44% of Randstad Holding, the now-$7.6 billion (sales) temp agency with 2,200 branches in about a dozen European and North American countries. Goldschmeding, who is now retired, is vice president of the supervisory board. Enjoys sailing

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father, opened a discount supermarket in the late 1970s. Later partnered with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Ahold. Last year exercised option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Has been boosting his stake in consumer goods company Orkla, on whose board he sits. Also set up a fund with two fellow Norwegians to invest in local companies. In June, married Mille Marie Treschow, a wealthy heir to an old family fortune. Reportedly owns one of the biggest sailboats in Europe and own island in the Caribbean.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of archetypal Texas oilman H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), whose oil empire supposedly started from poker winnings. Inherited most of Hunt Oil: older branch of the family took a big hit in silver market, but Ray stuck with the black gold, scored big with deal in Yemen. Now looking to move into natural gas with Peruvian pipeline deal. Known for D.C. connections thanks to fundraising for Bush, seat on Halliburton board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tech tycoon derives fortune from $1.9 billion (sales) HCL group, which provides software services and training. With outsourcing arm in Belfast, is among Northern Ireland’s biggest employers. Building two new campuses in India to house 15,000 employees each. A wine connoisseur, Nadar recently celebrated his 30th wedding anniversary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Hong Leong Group Malaysia, one of Asia’s leading financial conglomerates. Recently moved to simplify the complex structure of the family empire by cashing out a stake in a property company and selling it to one of its other holdings. Quek oversees the Malaysian operations while cousin and fellow billionaire Kwek Leng Beng oversees the Singaporean.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime head of Swiss-based luxury products group Richemont, whose brands include Cartier and Dunhill.  Gave up title as chief executive in September 2004, after 15-month stint leading a successful turnaround. Remains executive chairman. In native South Africa, chairs Remgro and VenFin, two family-controlled investment companies with interests in such industries as tobacco, technology and financial services. Passionate sportsman and former cricketer owns exclusive golf resort in South Africa; recently tried to buy U.K. rugby club with Wayne Huizenga. Helped create the Laureus Foundation, which funds 23 Sport for Good projects (including a midnight basketball league) with the goal of motivating underprivileged children. Founding Trustee Nelson Mandela Children’s Fund. Involved in nature conservation for 25 years, and just completed revolutionary wine cellar on family estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made first fortune with unlikely Japanese kiddie hit Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Sold to Rupert Murdoch in exchange for half of Fox Family Network. That channel later was sold to Disney for $5 billion. His take: $1.7 billion. Reinvested some of the proceeds to buy German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 from bankrupt Kirch Media.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. restored failing Bank of North Carolina before merging with NCNB 1982. Renamed NationsBank, now Bank of America. Spangler’s 32 million shares worth $1.5 billion; wife sits on board of directors. Savvy investor bought 2 million shares of RJR before 1989 KKR buyout. Other family holdings: National Gypsum (drywall), Golden Eagle Industries (construction). Daughter Anna runs venture capital firm Wakefield Group. Farmer’s son served 11 years as president of University of North Carolina. Tar Heel’s longtime hobby: grandfather clocks. “I’m interested in fixing broken clocks, not collecting clocks. The brass is more interesting than the wood.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife of Axel Springer, founder of $3 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany’s leading media groups now controls 55%. The company publishes Germany’s largest daily, tabloid Bild Zeitung, and leading conservative rag Die Welt. Has interests in growing number of countries including France, Spain, Hungary and the Czech Republic. Last year launched Forbes Russia and a Russian version of Newsweek. A Chinese venture is said to be in the works. Has established a foundation dedicated to researching heart and circulatory diseases in memory of her husband, who apparently suffered from both.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wee’s United Overseas Bank stands tall in the Singapore banking scene, both literally, as its skyscraper dominates the downtown skyline and figuratively, as Singapore’s second-largest bank by market capitalization (after state-controlled DBS Group). Successfully defeated a bid last year by Singapore’s investment company to buy his affiliated United Overseas Land. Now faces a deadline to divest the bank from any noncore assets by July 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: The corporate raider known for snapping up large stakes in distressed companies started out as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. Made headlines last year for accumulating his position, now 20%, in Havas, a global advertising and communications company with clients like MCI & Novartis. His eclectic portfolio also includes stakes in a plastics company, an African shipping network and Asian palm-oil plantations. In his spare time he is an avid comic collector, boasting 1,000 copies of classic comics by the likes of Pieds Nickles and Spirou. Plans to build a small home to house them, replete with a kitchen, so his friends can enjoy a snack while reading comics. He is also active in the Second Chance Foundation, which gives the down-and-out $20,000 to get back on their feet again.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation grocer took over family’s H.E. Butt supermarket chain 1971. Today more than 300 stores, $11 billion in sales. Still expanding: plans to double presence in Mexico to 20 stores. In Texas caters to yuppie tastes with upscale Central Market stores: eschews brands like Kraft and Coca-Cola in favor of gourmet foods, wine and cheese, in-store cafes. Former bag boy (and Wharton grad) donates 5% of pretax profit to charities, much to education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sided with brother Michael in the latter’s successful campaign to remove brother Günter and sister Daniela from the management of Tchibo Holding, the company he and his four siblings inherited from father, coffee baron Max Herz. Holds 34% stake of the holding, which includes $4.2 billion (sales) Tchibo and a 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, maker of Nivea products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stockbroker’s son started cable company with frat brother in 1963. Partner left 1981; Hostetter turned Continental Cablevision into nation’s largest privately held cable concern. Sold to US West for nearly $11 billion in 1996, under condition that Continental stay based in Boston. US West promptly moved cable operations (renamed MediaOne) to Denver. So Hostetter, furious, orchestrated sale of MediaOne to AT&T (whose cable systems were later sold to Comcast). Resigned from Ma Bell board last summer; oversees investments through Boston-based Pilot House.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Promise, one of four major Japanese consumer-loan firms. Profits last year fell 31.5% to $396 million on $3.7 billion in revenues, due to defaults on consumer loans. In 1997, Jinnai spent $100 million of his own fortune to establish a 1500-acre agricultural research center called “Jinnai Farm 21” in northern  Japan. Sophisticated computer-controlled devices tend to the plants and vegetation there in the hopes of mass producing organic vegetables. This is no pet cause. Last year he donated $114 million worth of Promise stock to the lab.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James, joined Wall Street specialist firm in 1945; Peter joined as director in 1973. Made money on the side in the 1990s investing in Alex. Brown, National Discount Brokers. Made a killing selling Spear, Leeds & Kellogg to Goldman Sachs in 2000 for $5.5 billion. Still believed to own sizable Goldman stake. Other investments in Presstek, Mercer International, MFC Bancorp. Accused by NASD in 2003 of engaging in fraudulent “wash and matched trades” to avoid taxes; cleared of all charges last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Handed reins of Quebec-based Saputo Inc., Canada’s largest dairy processor, to son last March; Lino Jr. now chief executive. Remains chairman. Cheese firm celebrated 50th anniversary with sales topping $3.6 billion in 2004; stock up 19% since last February. Company markets dairy products under several brands, including Gardenia, Dragone, Stella. Acquired Molfino Hermanos S.A., Argentina’s third-largest dairy processor, for $51 million in 2003. Now investing $11 million in Argentine dairies. Son of a cheesemaker, Saputo helped his Italian family start a mom-and-pop dairy company shortly after moving to Canada in 1952. Named chairman in 1969.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Iscar, one of the largest (by sales) manufacturers of carbide industrial cutting tools used by carmakers like GM and Ford. Son Eitan is Iscar’s president. Through his four industrial parks, Wertheimer also seeds high-tech startups in Israel. After fleeing Nazi Germany, the grade-school dropout joined the Palmach, the elite strike force of the Haganah, the pre-state defense organization. A former Israeli Parliament member he is today an ardent supporter of joint Israeli-Palestinian businesses. In 2002 he testified before Congress about his idea for a “new Marshall Plan” that advocates U.S. funding to revitalize the Middle East.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 49% of energy drink Red Bull; provided the original formula for the pick-me-up beverage while his Austrian partner Dietrich Mateschitz gave it the marketing buzz. Other holdings include $470 million (sales) T.C. Pharmaceuticals, a producer of energy drinks in Thailand, and 60% of a private hospital chain. Son Chalerm, who holds 2% stake in Red Bull, owns one of Asia’s leading wine producers Siam Winery, whose labels include Monsoon Valley.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents escaped Poland weeks before Nazi invasion. Sam born in Chicago 4 months after family’s arrival in America. With fraternity brother Robert Lurie (d. 1990) bought up cheap real estate throughout the U.S. from distressed owners. Rehabbing costs proved to be a bargain when construction costs for new buildings soared. The jeans-wearing businessman owns 125 million square feet of office space and 202,000 apartments. “I’ve always said that I am worth $29.53.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Mass media mogul oversees Verlagsgruppe Bauer, the company founded by his grandfather in 1875. The $2.2 billion (sales) German media company publishes over 120 magazines in 13 countries on 3 continents; in Germany controls 40% of all women’s magazines; in the U.S. titles include Soap Opera Update, Soaps in Depth and Woman’s World. Recently started publishing a more up-market men’s magazine called Matador. Ole!

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns over 50% of Caltagirone SpA, the industrial holding company which has cement, media and real estate interests. His Cementir subsidiary recently plowed its way into China, buying a Shanghai plant for $7.5 million. A vocal shareholder activist, he leads a group of shareholders at Banca Nazionale del Lavoro reportedly pushing for management change. Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, of which he is also a shareholder and board member, rejected an invitation to join the rebel shareholder pact at Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. In recent years unsuccessfully bid for Metrovacesa, a Spanish property holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of oil baron J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976). Spent 4 years in family business, then opted for the esthetic life; studied music at the San Francisco Conservatory. Sold family’s Getty Oil to Texaco for $10 billion 1986. Now a committed composer; works include “Joan and the Bells,” “The White Election” and “Victorian Scenes.” Baseball fan still dabbles in business: funding ReFlow, outfit that buys illiquid shares from mutual funds. Also founded winery, resort and restaurant business under PlumpJack name.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the 1980s Khan studied at the Moscow Institute of Steel & Alloys, where he met several members of what would later become the Alfa Group, headed by Mikhail Fridman. Khan became the point man for the group’s most lucrative business line, trading house Alfa-Eco. By 1994 Khan had helped make Alfa-Eco one of Russia’s largest private oil traders and had helped set up a big oil-for-sugar deal with Cuba. Last year Alfa-Eco was named in an investigation into Iraq’s oil-for-food deal. The company denies the charges. When Alfa took over oil giant TNK, it was Khan who was chosen to run the operation. Today TNK is half-owned by BP, but Khan remains executive director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chrome and porcelain still turning to gold for third-generation chief of plumbing business started in 1873. With sister Ruth, controls estimated $3.2 billion-sales Kohler empire: toilets, sinks, furniture, cabinets, engines, generators. Also golf: owns Whistling Straits course on Lake Michigan, site of last year’s PGA championship.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three surviving sons of cable pioneer John Elroy McCaw (youngest son, Keith, died 2002). Sons took over business after father’s death in 1969; Craig turned frail cable concern into cellular phone giant. Sold to AT&T for $11.5 billion in 1993. Invested proceeds in Nextel, other tech investments, but got hit hard in telecom crash. Still in the game with satellite company ICO, cellular outfit Microcell.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford business grad got start managing Bass family’s $50 million portfolio in 1970; lost money first 2 years. Acquired large stake in Disney 1984, went solo 2 years later. Cofounded Columbia Hospital 1987, bought Hospital Corporation of America 1994. Sold HCA stake last year, invested proceeds in Tenet Healthcare. Recently shedding oil and gas assets for additional liquidity; says he’s on the prowl for other buying opportunities. Purchased 3 million shares of Global Crossing last year, now owns 7.5% of beleaguered telecom. “I’m doing better than I’ve ever done. I’m happy, healthy, wealthy and wise, and that’s about it.” Wife, Darla Moore, a dealmaker in her own right, managing sizable assets since 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schoolteacher’s son got start as bank examiner, bought Dallas drugstore for $5,000 in 1961. Built into 100-store chain; sold to Eckerd for $50 million 12 years later. Went on shopping spree: chemicals, oil services, timber, sugar, fast food. Cached most of his holdings in publicly traded Valhi: metals, titanium dioxide, waste management. Legislation allowing burial of low-level nuclear waste in western Texas could be boon to business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale economics undergrad wrote thesis on improving delivery services via integrated network of planes and trucks. Worked as crop pilot, bought small stake in Arkansas aviation firm; turned into courier service Federal Express. Last year acquired Kinko’s for $2.4 billion. Also finances Alcon Entertainment (Chasing Liberty, My Dog Skip), minority owner of the Washington Redskins football team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), orthopedic surgeon who invented mobile hospital beds. Founded medical supply company Stryker Corp., heirs now control 30% of the company. When father, Lee, died in 1977 plane crash, John Brown (see) took over company. Architect Jon founder of Arcus Foundation, focuses on gay and lesbian rights, animal conservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), orthopedic surgeon who invented mobile hospital beds. Founded medical supply company Stryker Corp., heirs now control 30% of the company. When father, Lee, died in 1977 plane crash, John Brown (see) took over company. Ronda the only family member to sit on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Like Lukoil’s Leonid Fedun, Tsvetkov started out in the military. He graduated from the Air-Army Engineering Academy, served with Soviet forces in Afghanistan and reached the rank of lieutenant colonel. When the Soviet Union collapsed, Tsvetkov started a new career as an investment banker. In 1993, he established investment company Nikoil, whose first task was to make sure that the managers of new oil company Lukoil would be the big winners in their company’s 1994 privatization. Today Tsvetkov has a big stake in Lukoil; his investment bank, Nikoil, has acquired retail bank UralSib to become one of Russia’s largest private financial institutions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Johnson Electric, one of the world’s leading manufacturers of minimotors, founded in 1959 by his parents to make motors for toy boats. These days the motors are found in antilock braking systems, power drills, seat adjusters and blood pressure pumps. Year-end net profits were down 22% last year, due to rising copper and steel prices. Wang holds a master’s degree in electrical engineering from Purdue University in Indiana.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino visionary preparing for April opening of Wynn Las Vegas: $2.7 billion resort with 2,700 rooms, Ferrari dealership, permanent space for Wynn’s vaunted art collection. Son of a New York bingo parlor operator became keno manager at Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas. Bought Golden Nugget casino before building the Mirage, Treasure Island and Bellagio themed resorts. Sold Mirage to Kirk Kerkorian for $6.4 billion in 2000. Took Wynn Resorts public 2002: stock up 471% since offering. Now setting sights on Asia. Broke ground on Wynn Macau, $700 million casino in Far East gambling mecca.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile investment bank Allen & Co. has had a stellar run: claims to have had returns of more than 40% a year since the mid-1980s. Firm has long tradition of forging lucrative relationships with corporate leaders. Host of annual retreat for media bigwigs in Sun Valley, Idaho helped spawn some high-profile mergers like Disney and ABC. This year’s guests included many of The Forbes 400: Bill Gates, Barry Diller, Rupert Murdoch, Meg Whitman. Board member and large investor in Coca-Cola travels everywhere with Donnie, his black Labrador.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns and runs $1.3 billion (sales) Mango, makers of reasonably priced trendy women’s apparel. Opened his first store in Barcelona in 1984; now has 700 locations in 73 countries. A very private man, little is known about him other than the fact that his family came to Spain from Turkey in the 1960s and that he is rumored to love sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former supermarket manager started developing shopping centers in Iowa with late brother Martin in 1954. Took General Growth Properties public in 1993. Relocated to Chicago. Still serves as chairman, but son John oversees company's 200 million square feet of mall space.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive and a committed Buddhist, Chen delisted his flagship company Nan Fung Textiles back in 1989. Despite the economic downturn of the late 1990s, Chen seems to have fared well. He bought 12% of fellow billionaire Ng Teng Fong’ Sinoland and built up its portfolio of luxury properties, whose values have increased over 50% just in the past year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad got start trading options at Gruntal & Co. 1978; made $8,000 profit on first day. Founded hedge fund SAC Capital with $20 million 1992; now manages more than $4.5 billion in assets. Fund has average return of at least 40% annually over 12 years. Market mover: firm’s 40 portfolios believed to trade 20 million shares a day, accounting for as much as 3% of NYSE’s daily volume. Highly secretive investor commands highest performance fee in the business: 50% of the profits if certain benchmarks met. Avid art enthusiast (collects Andy Warhol), generous giver: with wife, Alex, serves on boards of Paul Tudor Jones’ (see) Robin Hood Foundation, Michael J. Fox Foundation. Last year they committed $3 million to build clinic at Greenwich Hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Crowned a billionaire following the $5.3 billion sale of Endemol, the TV production company he founded with Dutch compatriot John de Mol, to telecom giant Telefonica in 2000. Though Endemol garnered fame for pioneering the reality TV genre with hits like Fear Factor, Van Den Ende’s true passion rests with musical theater. His Stage Holding produces shows like Mamma Mia! in more than a dozen theaters throughout Europe. Theater hasn’t proven as lucrative. Last fall Stage opened Dodger Stages, a five-theater complex, off Broadway in New York City. But the last minute pullout of a financial backer shelved a key act during the theater’s inaugural season, and Dodger Theatricals, winner of 46 Tony Awards, recently closed a three-and-a-half-year 42nd Street revival at a loss.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Mediolanum SpA, life insurance and fund management company he cofounded. Longtime business ally of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who is Mediolanum’s second-largest shareholder, behind Doris. Net profit in the first six months of 2004 jumped 47% to $93.6 million. Near-term expansion plans include France, Germany and Spain. Serves on board of prominent Italian investment bank Mediobanca. Enjoys bicycling.

name: Billionaires
bio: The number two at Russian oil giant Lukoil, Fedun was born in Kiev, Ukraine and served as an officer in the nuclear missile forces. With the fall of communism Fedun adroitly transformed himself, learning the workings of the financial markets and starting a financial consultancy that helped Vagit Alekperov set up Lukoil. Coordinated the company’s privatization—in which managers like himself got big stakes.

name: Billionaires
bio: An annus horribilis for the co-chairman of staffing firm Adecco.  Last year Adecco announced possible accounting errors, prompting an investigation by the Swiss Exchange. Adecco shares plunged 35%, and the requisite shareholder class action suits followed shortly after. French authorities are also investigating potential violations of European laws governing fair competition.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns the privately held Djarum, one of the three big makers of clove cigarettes known as kreteks.The Djarum company was started by Hartono’s father in 1951 in the central part of the island of Java and now employs 75,000. Still wholly owned by the family. The company produces more than a dozen brands of kreteks, including vanilla and cherry flavored, and claims to control 70% of the kreteks sold in the U.S. market. Hartono also shares a controlling stake in one of Indonesia’s best-run banks, Bank of Central Asia, with the hedge fund Farallon Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2001 Citigroup bought Banamex, the big Mexican bank Hernandez was running at the time, for $12.5 billion. Hernandez pocketed almost $2 billion. Still chairs the Banamex board and retains a seat on Citigroup’s board. He’s also chairman of Mexico’s National Museum of History and spends his free time fixing up old cotton haciendas in Mexico’s Yucatán peninsula. Luxury hotel chain Aman Resorts has reportedly expressed interest in buying up one or two of the restored plantations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of coffee magnate Max Herz. After nasty family feud he and his sister Daniela sold their 40% combined stake in consumer products group Tchibo Holding to their mother and three siblings for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. With sister, has recently founded a private equity company Maryland GbmH to invest some of their money. An avid race horse fan, raises horses at the stud farm he owns in Schleswig-Holstein.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rising oil prices putting the squeeze on profits, but sure didn&#39t sidetrack initial public offering of Huntsman Corp., his giant chemical concern. Stock up sharply since the offering, but any bonanza likely will be short-lived: Says most of the proceeds will go to his cancer foundation: “I’ll keep just enough shares to live on.”

name: Billionaires
