bio: Former Enron president wisely left firm in 1996, uncomfortable with “asset-light” strategy. Bought Enron’s asset-rich liquid gas pipeline operations with college classmate William Morgan. Today controls over 35,000 miles of pipeline and some 100 terminals. Last year spent $150 million on pipelines and terminals from ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Royal Dutch/Shell. Poster boy for “proper” executive compensation, paying himself $1 a year and flying coach on company time. But payouts from limited partnership make sure he has plenty of cash to indulge in fly-fishing hobby.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a trade unionist dropped out of Harvard Ph.D. program after bout of writer’s block. Drifted for 6 years: drove New York City cab, studied harpsichord at Juilliard, consulted for Republican Party. At age 31 used $3,000 MasterCard line to start trading commodities (soybeans). Made quick $40,000, didn’t hedge; lost $23,000 in hours. Joined Commodities Corp., learned from veteran investor Michael Marcus: “He taught me you could make a million dollars.” Started Caxton Associates in 1983; hedge fund group has $10 billion under management. Size doesn’t always matter: returned $2 billion to investors last year to keep from diluting returns. Chairs Juilliard and conservative American Enterprise Institute; spent $2 million publishing fully illustrated version of the King James Bible.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over his father’s construction firm in 1981. Over the years helped expand group into property management and investments. Now publicly traded L.E. Lundberforetagen AB owns 157 properties and projects. Time off: curling (was once a junior world champion) and hunting.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bowing out of the Vivendi bidding war, cable’s once and future king still keeps the media world guessing. He surprised Rupert Murdoch with acquisition of big voting stake in News Corp.; spun off international cable businesses. Former engineer became right-hand man to TCI cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), sold TCI to Ma Bell in 1999 for $54 billion. Has kept his fingers in all things media ever since, aided by his trademark, elaborately complex financial maneuvering.

name: Billionaires
bio: With a Thai business partner created Red Bull energy drink and marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising and high-profile sponsorship of extreme sports. Last November acquired Jaguar’s Formula One racing team from Ford Motor, renamed it Red Bull Racing and hired veteran Grand Prix racer David Coulthard for 2005 season. Mateschitz, who owns 49% of the $1.6 billion (sales) company, is stepping back from the day-to-day business to spend more time on pet projects like Hangar-7, an event center that houses his historic aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls. A fit 60-year-old, Mateschitz claims he drinks ten cans a day of his concoction, but he still hasn’t been able to convince the French health authorities, who ban Red Bull’s sale in France, that it is safe to drink.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned MIT scholarship after designing unbeatable tic-tac-toe computer program. Worked on college computer magazine. Founded International Data Group 1964 to provide market research to computer makers. Launched Computerworld in 1967; later, PC World, Macworld. Added instructional books via popular Dummies series, trade shows. Today IDG publishes 300 magazines and newspapers in 85 countries, 400 technology-related Web sites. Big inroads in Asia: plans to invest $100 million in Vietnam, $200 million in India over the next 10 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped her then-husband, Amancio Ortega, make gowns and lingerie in their home. That business eventually became $5.8 billion (sales) Inditex, an apparel manufacturer that also owns Zara retail stores. Though divorced years ago, still holds 7% stake and until last June held a seat on the board. Also has holdings in a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns and in a company that is looking for cancer treatments in compounds found in the sea. She is also president of the Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven (see), left father’s real estate firm 1979, set up Equity Group Holdings; bought up small manufacturing companies: Chicago Pneumatic Tool, Western Pacific Industries, Ammco Tools. Acquired 25% stake in near-bankrupt real estate investment trust, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher (named after favorite trout stream in Montana). Acquired, revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell (see), left father’s real estate firm 1979, set up Equity Group Holdings; bought up small manufacturing companies: Chicago Pneumatic Tool, Western Pacific Industries, Ammco Tools. Acquired 25% stake in near-bankrupt real estate investment trust, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher (named after favorite trout stream in Montana). Acquired, revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker Schroder continues as a director of his family’s financial services company, Schroders Plc., which celebrated its 200th anniversary last year. Schroders manages $190 billion on behalf of clients in 26 countries. Family has 47% stake. Profits (before tax) in 2003 up 250%  under the continued turnaround of chief Michael Dobson.  Schroder flies planes and breeds "middle white" pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained as an oil engineer in Moscow, earned M.B.A. from Fordham University. Worked for Deloitte & Touche; became U.S. citizen. Teamed up with Roman Abramovich to start Runicom S.A., Swiss oil trading firm. In 1995 the duo partnered with Boris Berezovsky to gain control of oil giant Sibneft; Shvidler became president in 1998. With partners, pooled his oil, aluminum, meatpacking and other industrial assets in British holding company Millhouse Capital. Last year played a key role in ending merger talks between Sibneft and its larger Russian rival, Yukos, after the arrest of top Yukos shareholder Mikhail Khodorkovsky (who would have run the new company).

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable news pioneer remains Time Warner’s largest individual shareholder even after dumping most of his holdings. Operates own restaurant chain, Ted’s Montana Grill, in 9 states. Signature dish: bison burgers. Each location replicates saloons of the Wild West. Ardent conservationist, America’s largest private landowner: 1.8 million acres in 10 states.

name: Billionaires
bio: OYoungest billionaire is also a prince. On his 18th birthday inherited the fortune left to him by his father, which included extensive real estate holdings, valuable art and a tech company. His 30,000 hectares of wood land in Germany is considered one of the largest forestry holdings in Europe. Now lives in one of the family castles at Schloss Emmeram with mother Gloria and older sisters Maria Theresia and Elisabeth.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a failed 1997 attempt to become Hong Kong’s first chief executive, headed the Hong Kong Trade Development Council for four years. In 2002 returned to the helm of Wheelock & Co., the company founded by his father-in-law, Sir Y.K. Pao. Now has been reappointed to head the council and is even mentioned as a possible candidate for Hong Kong’s chief executive post in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Upturn in oil and gas prices helping first family of Fort Worth overcome bad late-1990s tech bets. Oil-and-gas-exploration company getting ready to drill wells off the coast of Nova Scotia. Also owns stakes in Human Genome Sciences, John Wiley & Sons. Father and family patriarch, Perry, inherited slice of uncle Sid Richardson’s oil fortune after he died in 1951. Expanded empire. Handed family business to eldest son Sid in 1968, who brought in Stanford business school chum Richard Rainwater (see) in 1970. They engineered white knight Disney investment. Brother Ed opted for Yale’s architecture school; built adobe homes in New Mexico and funded the now financially troubled Biosphere. Family responsible for revitalization of downtown Fort Worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker, heads one of Spain’s leading financial institutions, Banco Santander Central Hispano. Struck a big deal last year to buy British mortgage bank Abbey National for $15 billion. Faces potential scandal: Botín is standing trial in Madrid, charged with misspending $200 mil of bank funds in early retirement payments to two former top executives, whose departure in 2001 and 2002 ended a power struggle at the bank. If forced to step down, has a capable heir apparent: daughter Ana Patricia Botín, who chairs bank’s retail unit Banestos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable entrepreneur got start filming sports events, selling footage to television stations. Founded Teleguide in 1960 to wire New York City hotel rooms with cable television. Founded HBO 1971; traded his stake to his partner, the old Time Inc., in 1973 in exchange for a nascent New York cable system that provided residential service to 1,500 customers. Cablevision now the nation’s 6th-largest cable operator, with 3 million subscribers, all in N.Y. area. Owns pro basketball’s New York Knicks, hockey’s New York Rangers, Madison Square Garden. Son, James, runs the company, but recent disagreements with father over VOOM satellite TV service causing some observers to question just how much longer.

name: Billionaires
bio: His eponymous Godrej Group, a $1.2 billion (sales) consumer goods conglomerate, makes soaps, hair dyes, cooking oil and office furniture. Family is also one of Mumbai’s biggest landowners. With actor Richard Gere, wife, Parmeshwar, heads AIDS awareness program, Heroes Project, backed by the Gates Foundation and the Kaiser Family Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of five surviving grandchildren of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Today the empire owns newspapers (flagship: San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, A&E, Lifetime), TV and radio stations. Also real estate. Recent state approval will allow some development of prime parcel along California coast. William III a partner at Silicon Valley venture capital shop Kleiner Perkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only daughter of coffee magnate Max Herz. In mid-2003, after nasty family feud, she and older brother Günter sold their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding to their three brothers and mother for an estimated $5 billion. The pair has recently used some of the proceeds to establish private equity firm Maryland GmbH.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout bought used garbage truck in 1962, transformed small trash-hauling operation into waste-management behemoth WMX. Resigned 1984. Bought 19-store video-rental chain Blockbuster 1987, sold to Viacom for $8.4 billion 7 years later. Back to trash: bought Republic Waste 1995 for $27 million; Republic Services stake now worth $40 million. Also investments in Auto-Nation (car dealerships), Boca Resorts (lodging). Sold stake in Extended Stay America to Stephen Schwarzman’s Blackstone Group for $185 million last year. Sold Florida Marlins 2 years after winning 1997 World Series; still owns pro football’s Miami Dolphins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Undisputed king of shopping malls in his native Philippines under his company SM Prime. For a decade has followed a strategy of opening at least 2 malls a year, and plans to have 23 malls in operation by the end of this year. Sy has also filed to take public his private holding company SM Investments, which should easily be one of the Philippines’ largest IPOs in years. Also under construction is the Mall of Asia on Manila’s waterfront, which promises to be one of the largest malls in the world when it opens late this year. Also the largest operator of movie theaters; last year he announced the banning of soft porn movies in all his theaters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned $2 million investment into $1.5 billion (sales) Taylor Corp. printing empire: wedding invites, stationery, magazines. Still involved but stepped down as chief executive in 2001; concentrates on philanthropy, new agribusiness selling liquefied eggs to food processors. Owner of pro basketball’s Minnesota Timberwolves, passed on buying pro football’s Minnesota Vikings.

name: Billionaires
bio:
World War II infantryman, pharmaceutical entrepreneur made fat fortune helping 
others shed pounds. Created Slim-Fast nutritional supplements late 1970s, sold to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000. Continues healthy pursuits by funding Mayo Clinic. Active supporter of Israeli-Arab peace initiatives through his Center for Middle East Peace and Economic Cooperation. “Violence and warfare should be eliminated from man’s actions.”

name: Billionaires
bio: One of five surviving grandchildren of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Today the empire owns newspapers (flagship: San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, A&E, Lifetime), TV and radio stations. Also real estate. Recent state approval will allow some development of prime parcel along California coast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first drugstore in 1969. Now the Jean Coutu Group includes more than 2196 stores in the U.S. and Canada, which makes it North America’s fourth-largest pharmacy chain. Company spent $2.4 billion to acquire Eckerd from J.C. Penney last year; also operates Brooks Pharmacy in New England. Coutu relinquished the chief executive title to son François in September 2002, but remains chairman. Son Michel is chief executive of the U.S. business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family’s scrap metal business into a cascade of assets in media, utilities and oil. Investments include a stake in German media behemoth Bertelsmann. Known as a workaholic who claims he’ll never retire, Baron Frere is a connoisseur of fine wine and co-owner, with French billionaire Bernard Arnault, of the Château Cheval Blanc vineyard. In 2004 the Financial Times European edition editorialized that Frere was one of the most important European businessmen ever, responsible for pioneering cross-border consolidation.

Today the empire owns newspapers (flagship: San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, A&E, Lifetime), TV and radio stations. Also real estate. Recent state approval will allow some development of prime parcel along California coast.

Also real estate. Recent state approval will allow some development of prime parcel along California coast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime land-use lawyer planted vines north of San Francisco mid-1970s, released first Kendall-Jackson wine in 1982. Today his Jackson Family Estates encompasses 20 brands (Camelot, Château Lassègue), selling an estimated 5 million cases of wine a year. Looked to retire in 2000, put K-J up for sale for $1.7 billion, changed mind. Expanding into boutique wineries with wife, Barbara Banke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of high school at age 14 to help run family’s dairy business during Depression. Opened ice cream store with siblings 1940; built 220-store United Dairy Farmers chain. Diversified into finance with small S&Ls. Today American Financial Group: big stakes in insurance, banking. Longtime co-owner of pro baseball’s Cincinnati Reds donates tickets to local school kids, civic workers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Campbell Soup accountant joined animal nutritionist Paul Iams’ pet-food firm 1970; succeeded Iams 1975, bought him out 1982. Built company by catering to high-end breeders and veterinarians, “focusing on the dog and cat as the customer.” Sold Iams to Procter & Gamble for $2.3 billion in 1999. Stays busy feeding Mathile Family Foundation, Center for Entrepreneurial Education in Dayton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Food king mourning loss of brother Harrison, who died last March. Power struggle for McCain Foods had led to strained relations between the billionaire brothers for over a decade; Wallace forced out in 1993. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods in 1995. Plentiful 2004: Maple Leaf revenues up 26%, profits up 200%. Wallace’s daughter is aspiring singer Eleanor McCain, who waxed on about the brothers’ long-standing feud in her 2001 debut album.

name: Billionaires
bio: South African native graduated University of Witwatersrand, moved to U.S. to take faculty position at UCLA’s medical school. Left to commercialize research on new drug delivery systems. First company, VivoRx, developed new islet cell transplantation technique for diabetics. Tangled with investors, left to form American Bioscience. Developed first proprietary drug, Abraxane, reengineered form of cancer blockbuster Taxol. Bought generic-drug manufacturer American Pharmaceutical Partners to make, market drug; stock price, and personal wealth, soared after winning FDA approval earlier this year. Bought oncology drug manufacturing plant in Switzerland to open European, South American markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-granddaughter of Franz Ströher, the wigmaker who founded Wella AG, one of world’s biggest professional hair care groups. Last March she and her family sold out to Procter & Gamble for $4 billion; she pocketed 25%. She and her husband, a former male nurse, are known for their collection of contemporary German art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surviving widow of famed investor Laurence Tisch (d. 2003). With brother Preston (see), Laurence start with New Jersey hotel in 1946; later owned the Drake, Belmont Plaza, Regency. Took control of Loews Theatres 1959, diversified interests now include insurance (CNA Financial), watches (Bulova), oil drilling (Diamond Offshore Drilling), tobacco (Lorillard). Larry long known for bearish pessimism; Preston’s son Jonathan now at helm, sees brighter future. Preston co-owner New York Giants pro football franchise. Family philanthropy: donations to NYU alone exceed $50 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wily steel investor bought up shares in U.K.-based Corus in 2002 when its shares were depressed, becoming one of the first Russian tycoons to buy shares in a global corporation.  When the parent company ordered its subsidiary to shed noncore assets—the state-of-the-art Oskol Steel Mill and the Lebedinsky Iron Ore Mining & Processing Facility—Usmanov seized the opportunity: He sold both companies to Interfin Group, which he controls. Last year, in partnership with Anisimov, bought Boris Ivanishvili’s metallurgical company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Expanded industrial empire by saving Morrison Knudsen—builder of San Francisco Bay Bridge, Hoover Dam—from bankruptcy 1996. Renamed Washington Group International, filed Chapter 11. Restructured, took public 2 years later; today sales top $2.5 billion, 27,000 employees. Diversified: electricity, nuclear services, homeland security; recently picked up engineering and mining contracts in Iraq. Owns Canada’s largest tug and barge company. Longtime Republican celebrated 70th birthday with 3-day party; guests included Oprah Winfrey (see). Owns island with golf course in British Columbia. Also spends time overhauling wrecked 204-foot yacht.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once bullish video game king Nintendo seems to be losing its momentum thanks to stiff competition from Sony and Miscrosoft. Sales in the U.S. have lagged. Profits for the fiscal year ended March 2004 were $316 million, half of what they were a year earlier. Nintendo won't claim defeat yet. It has already introduces new advanced gaming devices featuring LCD screens and voice recognition. Expect Nintendo to unveil an advanced version of Gamecube at the famed E3 (Electronic Entertainment Expo) this year. Though his company peddles increasingly high-tech video game devices, Yamauchi, former chief executive and a substantial Nintendo shareholder, prefers to play traditional Asian chess known as "Go".

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of four brothers, Dhanin was just 25 when he took over the family’s small seed shop. Transformed it into one of the world’s largest suppliers of animal feed. His CP Group has faced growing competition in its core agribusiness operations over the past year and its telecom units are struggling with debt. CP, however, intends to keep expanding its China operations with plans to almost double the number of Shanghai-based Lotus supercenter outlets to 86.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter’s son founded and still runs Portugal’s leading retailer, Sonae GSPS, owner of Modelo Continente superstores and supermarkets. Owns 53.1% of the group, which also has interests in a daily newspaper, a radio station, real estate, shopping centers and a manufacturer of wood panels. Sons Nuno and Paulo and daughter Claudia, all work in the organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former money manager for George Soros famous for orchestrating boss’ billion-dollar raid on the British pound in 1992. Timely long and short positions helped generate string of 30% returns for Soros’ Quantum Fund. Got start as a stock analyst for Pittsburgh National Bank, started Duquesne Capital Management 1981. Left to work for hero Soros 1988; believed to have kept 30% of mentor’s incentive fee. Parted from Soros in 2000 after sustaining massive tech sector losses. Returned to Duquesne Capital to run No Margin Fund. Former director of Paul Tudor Jones’ (see) Robin Hood Foundation. “Once you make a lot of money, it’s incredibly enjoyable to give it away. It’s a way to satisfy the soul.”

name: Billionaires
bio:
Son of former real estate developer Donald and wife, Doris, who founded Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Six stores opened within first year. Pioneered customer convenience by arranging by size, not style. Now over 3,000 locations with expanded empire including Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994.) Last year, after 35 years running Gap, parents handed control of company, and nearly half their stock holdings, to next generation of Fishers. Eldest son, Robert (see,) now serves as Gap chairman.
John branched off from the family business to found investment outfit Pisces but still holds a significant stake in the retailer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli immigrant spent his 20s learning the buyout business alongside older brother Alec at Gores Technology Group. They split in 1995 and Tom now runs Platinum Equity; conglomerate manages 20 companies with $6 billion in sales. Patiently rebuilds distressed companies before selling them at a profit. Raised $750 million fund last year—his first time investing other people’s money. Purchased famed MCA complex in Beverly Hills, former Global Crossing headquarters; his brother Sam’s Paradigm talent agency will occupy one building. Buyout king now funding a movie about a love story set in revolution-era Cuba; actor pal Andy Garcia will star and direct.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wife Ann inherited big Wal-Mart stake from father, James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail chain with brother Sam. Stan made money as a real estate developer, including shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Also owns more than 1 million acres of ranch land. Sports nut owns stake in pro football’s St. Louis Rams, basketball’s Denver Nuggets and hockey’s Colorado Avalanche.

name: Billionaires
bio: Joined father’s insurance company after earning degree from Princeton; took over company in 1965. Accelerated growth by targeting high-risk drivers; took Progressive public 1971. Recent focus: high-tech device that monitors customer’s driving habits and sets rate accordingly. Art collector has lined walls of corporate offices with more than 6,000 pieces of contemporary art. Supports Guggenheim Museum, Cleveland Museum of Art, Case Western Reserve University. Big Democratic contributor to groups opposed to President Bush.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance invented soup-condensing process while working at uncle’s Campbell Preserve Co. Bought out uncle in 1914. Malone inherited from son John Jr. Interests include Philadelphia-area philanthropy, horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: With J. Willard Marriott Jr. (see), sons of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started first root beer stand in 1927, opened first Marriott hotel in 1957; split empire 1993. Richard runs hotel-owner Host Marriott; J.W. Jr. manages Marriott International. Grumbling by Richard, other hotel owners over J.W.’s high operating fees subsided with new management contracts, recovering travel business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Less lauded, far less wealthy partner of Warren Buffett, still plays integral role at Berkshire Hathaway. Vice chairman since 1978, demands intense number-crunching analysis of investments. Met Buffett in 1959; soon began investing in Berkshire. Other investments: substantial stakes in Costco Wholesale (discount retail), Daily Journal (legal news), Price Legacy (real estate investments). Education enthusiast funded new wing at Pasadena’s Huntington Library; on board of Harvard-Westlake School.

name: Billionaires
bio: Traveling salesman's son dropped out of high school in 9th grade. Moved to Detroit after World War II, borrowed $1,800 to buy diner, sold for modest profit. Turned to building homes in Arizona; lost most of it in real estate crash of 1964. Moved to Los Angeles, bought more property. Then leveraged buyouts: Dole Food, Hawaiian real estate giant Castle & Cooke. Prominent GOP fundraiser also holds stake in Pacific Holdings, conglomerate that owns largest chassismaker in the U.S. Equine enthusiast keeps 400 Arabian horses on farm in California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Samueli (see) while working at TRW’s chip design division. Founded Broadcom in 1991 out of spare bedroom in Nicholas’ house to make high-speed telecom chips. Took public 1998. Nicholas was a hard-charging workhorse until he quit abruptly in 2003 to spend time with his family. He recently donated $10 million to his children’s school in California. Samueli serves as chief engineer, chairman of Broadcom.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Aruze, Japan&#39s largest Pachinko slot machine manufacturers. The company had a miserable year due to a defective new machine. The results: Sales fell 30% to $722 million, while profits of $16 million were just 10% of what Aruze posted in 2003. But across the Pacific, Okada is enjoying the honeymoon period with business partner, U.S. gaming tycoon Steve Wynn, as both anticipate the grand opening of the joint casino resort ‘Wynn Las Vegas’ next April. Okada was granted an approval for a two-year manufacturer&#39s license from the Nevada Gaming Commission this year, which could mean a big win for his U.S. subsidiary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star racecar driver retired from racing in 1965 at age 28. Worked for Alcoa; left, bought Chevy dealership. Started Penske Corp. in 1969. Now controls over 200 dealerships in the U.S. and Europe; truck leasing business, auto parts manufacturer. Also chairman of United Auto Group, nation’s second-largest auto dealer. Owns 2 Indy car teams, 3 Nascar teams; part-owner of Deer Valley ski resort in Utah. In the driver’s seat as chairman of Detroit’s host committee for the 2006 Super Bowl.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive oil baron built Argentina’s largest energy company before selling out to Petrobras in 2002 for $1 billion. Now controls Molinos Rio de la Plata, Argentina’s largest packaged foods company. Deeply religious, Perez Companc and wife, Maria Carmen, have seven children—sons Luis and Jorge help run Molinos—and donate generously to Catholic charities. Gregorio spends holidays tooling around his country retreat in a red Ferrari F50, which sells for roughly $500,000.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained nuclear engineer, he taught at the University of Milan, then became an AC Nielsen  researcher before joining the family firm in 1976. He turned his family’s ailing Naples-based drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem, the second-largest drug wholesaler in Europe. Racing to keep up with Celesio, the company has been buying drugstores across Europe. In December surprised investors when he assumed the title of executive deputy chairman, relinquishing the chief executive post. Hobby: yachts. Lives in tax-haven Monaco but can be found at the Ritz when in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2003 sales: $5.5 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (207 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama includes Robert’s two youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, living with his ex-wife. Liesel and Matthew filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family has offshore trusts. Tom serves as chief executive of Pritzker Organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State University turned down proposal for adult-education program, John, humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge, left to start for-profit University of Phoenix; took public as Apollo Group in 1994. Now nation’s largest private university system: more than 200,000 students, 50 campuses, 90 learning centers. John resigned as chairman in 2004; remains on board. Iconoclast supports cloning research, marijuana legalization. Son, Peter, serves as Apollo’s senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State University turned down proposal for adult-education program, father John, a humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge, left to start for-profit University of Phoenix; took public as Apollo Group in 1994. Now nation’s largest private university system: more than 200,000 students, 50 campuses, 90 learning centers. John resigned as chairman in 2004; remains on board. Iconoclast supports cloning research, marijuana legalization. Son, Peter, serves as Apollo’s senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), orthopedic surgeon who invented mobile hospital beds. Founded medical supply company Stryker Corp., heirs now control 30% of the company. When father, Lee, died in 1977 plane crash, John Brown (see) took over company. Pat runs Stryker Sonoma Vineyard on 32 acres in Alexander Valley.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ethnic Chinese entrepreneur has amassed a mostly private fortune that includes both the national carrier Air Philippines and international carrier Philippine Airlines as well as the nation’s largest cigarette company, Fortune Tobacco. Also major liquor company Tanduay. His weakest link now is Asia Brewery, which has been losing market share to the much stronger San Miguel. Known for flying helicopters and a passion for learning Chinese history; paid a professor from China to move to Manila to be his private tutor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out in the quarrying business. Plowed those profits into $410 million (sales) Peel Acquisitions, which owns, develops and manages properties ranging from airports and shopping centers to ports and canals. Reclusive billionaire took his company private in August

name: Billionaires
bio: This horse-loving former banker has managed to stay out of the headlines since he sold Banco Bozano, Simonsen, which he co-founded, to Spain’s Banco Santander Central Hispano in 2000. His 11% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer is worth $660 million. Reportedly lives in Greenwich, Conn. and has a pied-à-terre in Rio de Janeiro.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over family’s shoe business. Still runs the $2.7 billion (sales) Deichman-Schuhe GmbH, now one of Europe’s largest shoe retailers. Has nearly 2,000 stores in 12 countries; in the U.S. operates Off Broadway and Rack Room shoes chains. A German magazine last year named Deichman-Schuhe one of the  50 best companies to work for, thanks to its generous employee benefits programs. Committed philanthropist, funds a program for leprosy victims in India, which he visits yearly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance invented soup-condensing process while working at uncle’s Campbell Preserve Co. Bought out uncle in 1914. Dorrance inherited from son John Jr. Sits on Campbell board, dabbles in real estate, airplanes.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of three children of Joyce Hall (d. 1982), preacher’s son who turned fuzzy feelings into hard cash after founding postcard manufacturer Hallmark in 1910. Now world’s largest greeting-card company. Siblings own two-thirds of $4.3 billion (sales) company. Donald chairman; son, Don Jr., serves as CEO. Family active in Kansas City philanthropy: more than $50 million in donations to area children’s hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billion-dollar beneficiary of Citigroup’s 2001 buyout of Banamex, Harp now spends much of his time tending to his nation’s poor. A cousin of Carlos Slim, Harp formed a foundation which gave away prize money to physically disabled Mexican athletes competing in the Paralympic Games last year in Athens. Also promotes artistry of indigenous Mexicans in the poor region of Oaxaca.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained mathematician, Hector cofounded German software giant SAP with four former IBM colleagues. He successfully built up the North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling-out with his partners. His charitable foundation supports cancer and AIDS research, art and historical preservation. He holds an honorary professorship of mathematics at the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences, information technology and technology fields.

name: Billionaires
bio: Retired UC San Diego engineering professor founded Qualcomm in 1985. Won over telecom industry with his patented new wireless protocol, called code division multiple access technology (CDMA). Highflier on the Big Board until telecom bust, but lately stock is up on mobile phone sales, new customers in India, China. Recently pledged $100 million to San Diego Symphony.

name: Billionaires
bio: A carpenter by trade, Jové opened his own business in 1980. Turned it into a leading real estate company called FADESA Immobiliaria, which he took public in April 2004. The $675 million (sales) has seen revenues grow almost sixfold from 1998-2003, thanks to construction boom in Spain and Portugal. Recently won a contract to build a 16,000-bed, 3,000-villa resort in Morocco. Company is well known in Spain for sponsoring the first division soccer team, Deportivo A Coruña. Hobbies: collects art from the Spanish province of Galicia and, appropriately enough, enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 1,875 pharmacies to create one of the biggest pharmacy chains in North America. The Edmonton-based Katz—pronounced “Cates”—Group is also one of Canada’s largest private companies. Katz bought up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hired capable execs to turn the chains around. This strategy failed for the first time after Katz’s U.S. arm, Snyder&#39s Drug Stores, bought bankrupt Drug Emporium. Snyder&#39s emerged from U.S. bankruptcy court last year after shedding the Drug Emporium stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Used car salesman changed course after placing a $3 ad in the Chicago Tribune to sell his old computer. Saw potential in discount computer sales, started Computer Discount Warehouse 1984. Today CDW sells some $5 billion in computer gear, mostly to businesses, government. Stepped down as chief executive in 2001. Now managing personal portfolio; invests in low-risk stocks and bonds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in the Russian city of Kirov, studied at the Moscow Institute of Steel & Alloys with billionaires Mikhail Fridman and German Khan. With Fridman founded Alfa Group in 1989. As the head of Crown Resources, a Swiss outfit, in the mid-1990s, Kuzmichov handled raw materials exports for Alfa Group. But in November 2002 the oil tanker Prestige, chartered by Crown Resources, broke up in a storm off the Spanish coast, spewing some 20,000 tons of fuel oil into the ocean. Alfa Group immediately unloaded Crown Resources. Now has a variety of responsibilities: heads up Alfa Group’s raw-materials trading business, Alfa-Eco; serves on the board of Alfa Finance Holdings, which oversees the group’s oil and finance interests; and also heads up a venture fund called Russian Technologies, which specializes in research and development in the fields of nanotechnology and biotechnology.

name: Billionaires
bio: The wealthiest former-Soviet-intelligence-officer-turned-businessman, Lebedev is also a parliamentary deputy. As a KGB agent in the 1980s he was involved in the effort to prevent capital flight from the Soviet Union. He also worked for five years at the Soviet embassy in London. As a businessman Lebedev has been especially successful in portfolio investing. His sizable holdings in Unified Energy Systems and Gazprom are now worth six times more than his core business, Nationalny Reservny Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in London’s East End, dropped out of high school to help expand family’s catering business. Gradually moved into currency trading in the late 1970s; now has homes in Lyford Cay, Bahamas; Orlando, Florida and land in Argentina. Main investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 100 companies including several San Diego biotech outfits, a Russian oil & gas concern and Hotspot FX, a virtual currency marketplace. Real estate holdings include Isleworth Country Club, whose residents include Tiger Woods and Shaquille O’Neal; Lake Nona Golf & Country Club, home to golfers Ernie Els, Annika Sorenstam and Sergio Garcia. In March hosting Tavistock Cup, lavish team competition between these two Florida clubs and their big-name professionals. Also developing 3,600 acres in the Bahamas.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of Russia’s most mysterious businessmen. Was born in Bukhara, Uzbekistan and graduated from Tashkent State University’s Eastern studies department. Put his Arabic skills to work in the Soviet military in Libya and Iraq. Early in his business career he hooked up with the Chernoy brothers and their Trans World Group, once the largest metal trader in Russia. Now controls UGMK Group, the second-largest nonferrous metals (gold, zinc, copper, etc.) holding company in the country.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Richard Marriott, sons of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started first root beer stand in 1927, opened first Marriott hotel in 1957; split empire 1993. Richard runs hotel-owner Host Marriott; J.W. Jr. manages Marriott International. Grumbling by Richard, other hotel owners over J.W.’s high operating fees subsided with new management contracts, recovering travel business.

name: Billionaires

Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama includes Robert’s two youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, living with his ex-wife. Liesel and Matthew filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family has offshore trusts. Case recently settled. Penny still serves chief of Hyatt’s senior housing division.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Nicholas (see) while working at TRW’s chip design division. Founded Broadcom in 1991 out of spare bedroom in Nicholas’ house to make high-speed telecom chips. Took public 1998. Nicholas was a hard-charging workhorse until he quit abruptly in 2003 to spend time with his family. Samueli serves as chief engineer, chairman of Broadcom.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born near Shanghai, Rong is chairman of CITIC Pacific, a conglomerate with interests in infrastructure, airlines and real estate. CITIC Pacific is controlled by state-owned China International Trust and Investment Co. Rong, 62, worked in China's Ministry of Electric Power for 14 years before coming to Hong Kong in 1978.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Son of Montreal tobacco and candy wholesaler. Wharton M.B.A.; law degrees from McGill, Harvard. Never took bar exam: “Practicing law is the opposite of having sex. Even when it’s good, it’s bad.” Got start in real estate working at Cabot, Cabot & Forbes. Left to form Boston Properties: $6.5 billion REIT owns 45 million square feet of mostly East Coast commercial space. Second career: publishing. Owns U.S. News & World Report; bought, turned around New York’s 
Daily News. Sold Fast Company magazine at tech boom peak for $365 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Upturn in oil and gas prices helping first family of Fort Worth overcome bad late-1990s tech bets. Oil-and-gas-exploration company getting ready to drill wells off the coast of Nova Scotia. Also owns stakes in Human Genome Sciences, John Wiley & Sons. Father and family patriarch, Perry, inherited slice of uncle Sid Richardson’s oil fortune after he died in 1951. Expanded empire. Handed family business to eldest son Sid in 1968, who brought in Stanford business school chum Richard Rainwater (see) in 1970. They engineered white knight Disney investment. Brother Ed opted for Yale’s architecture school; built adobe homes in New Mexico and funded the now financially troubled Biosphere. Family responsible for revitalization of downtown Fort Worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buck fronted partner Fred DeLuca (see) cash to open sub shop to help pay for college in 1965. Shop floundered, so DeLuca opened a second to create aura of success. Partners have opened 21,870 Subways since—19,000 in U.S. alone, giving Subway more domestic storefronts than McDonald’s. Next goal: repeating the feat overseas. Keeps overhead low, charges minimal franchise fees. But ballooning store count means negative same-store sales, keeping worried operators on their toes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Hyundai, South Korea’s largest car maker with more than 50,000 employees worldwide and sales of $32 billion in 2004.  South Korean car exports showed a 40% growth last year. Hyundai Group used to be one of Korea’s largest conglomerates before being dissembled following the 1998 Asian financial crisis.  Hyundai Motor was given to Mong-Koo, second son of Hyundai conglomerate founder Chung Ju-Yung.

Billionaires
bio: A count whose wealth is “secure” for now. Holds stakes in the world’s largest producer of locks Assa Abloy and in one of the largest publicly traded security companies, Securitas AB. Other holdings include shares in Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures, and 44% of Attendo Senior Care, a private company that provides alarms and communication systems to monitor senior citizens. Received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1964.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largest private landowner in California still sparring with environmentalists, despite having sold thousands of acres of land to preservationists. “Red” operated small lumber mill with father in 1940s. Took Sierra Pacific public 1969; got tired of answering to Wall Street, took private 5 years later. Borrowed $460 million to buy 522,000 acres in 1988, making him among the nation’s largest private landowners. Expanded into Washington state: built 13th sawmill in Aberdeen. Two sons work in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farm-boy-turned-thrift-trader bought first bank in 1975 for $1.2 million, later sold for $80 million. Biggest windfall came in 2002: sold California’s Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion; personal stake now worth more than $1 billion. Other investments include auto-finance company AmeriCredit, McMoran Exploration oil and gas outfit. Owns a 140,000-acre cattle ranch in New Mexico, home to 15 families. Spends idle time flying in his private jet to LA to shop for cowboy hats.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock in his Benesse Corp., best known for its distance learning and test prep schools, was up 22% last year. Still, it’s core education courses continue to shrink due to changes in Japanese educational system and fewer school-age kids. Career-oriented Japanese women are also having fewer children. So the company is successfully diversifying into new areas like day-care and nursing care, a likely boon as Japan’s baby boomers hit their twilight years. Also has partnership with U.S. toy company LeapFrog to develop Japanese versions of its hugely popular educational toys. And the Berlitz subsidiary provides language training around the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Also known as the Viscount Rothermere, Harmsworth assumed leadership of the Daily Mail and General Trust newspaper conglomerate from his father at the tender age of 30. Now 37, he’s proven adept at guiding DMGT in a U.K. newspaper market that is in clear decline. Circulation of the flagship Daily Mail shrank by one-half a percentage point last year. On a brighter note the paper actually outperformed most of its competition while advertising revenues rose. DMGT’s controversial share structure gives Rothermere and family voting control despite minority ownership.

name: Billionaires
bio: This steel tycoon, a close associate of fellow billionaire Igor Zyuzin, dislikes the limelight. The former commercial director of Kuznets Coal in 1995 became president of Swiss firm Conares Holding, the main foreign trade operator for giant Mechel Steel Group. Had his coming-out party in October, when he was named Mechel’s general director and when Mechel listed on the New York Stock Exchange, raising $290 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of four children of Sam Curtis Johnson, who passed away in May. Sam expanded floor wax firm founded by great-grandfather in 1886 by introducing household cleaning staples (Glade, Pledge), bug repellants (Off, Raid). Handed company over to fifth generation in 2000, but remained the public face through series of folksy ads. Recent years spent discussing his fight with alcoholism, making documentary film about troubled relationship with father. Sent all kids to alma mater Cornell University, then brought into family business. Fisk chairman of S.C. Johnson. Brother Curtis oversees commercial markets operation. Sister Helen heads up Johnson Outdoors. Other sister Winnie part-time project coordinator. Family left indelible stamp on hometown of Racine, commissioning Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters. Big backers of Cornell, Smithsonian Institution, Nature Conservancy, Racine Art Museum.

bio: First cousins partnered with fellow Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Bought underperforming companies using junk bonds, reworked balance sheet, sold for profit. Kohlberg exited in 1987. “Barbarians at the gate” best known for $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Recent spending spree: PanAmSat (satellites), Sealy Mattress, Auto-Teile-Unger (German auto parts). Also sprucing up Primedia: sold off moneylosing New York and Seventeen magazines; developing TV shows to boost Hot Rod, Motor Trend brands. High-profile New York socialite big donor to Metropolitan Museum; wife, Marie-Josée, former director of poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cogen Technologies founder opted for cash and stock when he sold the nation’s largest privately held power company to Enron for $1.5 billion in 1999. Became a hometown hero after bringing pro football expansion team to Houston. Avid horseman controls Stonerside Stables, winner of 57 Graded Stake horse races. Civic-minded: taking leading role in project to revitalize downtown Houston with pedestrian-friendly streets and gardens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wildcatter founded Mitchell Energy & Development in 1946, struck gold in north Texas gas fields. Sold to Devon Energy in 2001 for $3.5 billion. Longtime environmentalist opposed oil drilling in Alaska wildlife refuge, funded $10 million National Academies study on sustainable development and population growth. Donated $1.2 million to Texas A&M University to fund Giant Magellan Telescope.

Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama includes Robert’s two youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, living with his ex-wife. Liesel and Matthew filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family has offshore trusts. Case recently settled. Tony, with brother, J.B., runs a venture capital fund, invests in technology, manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner James Goodnight (see) owners of SAS Institute, world’s largest privately held software company (sales: $1.3 billion). Designs advanced statistical-modeling software for pharmaceutical giants such as Merck and Eli Lilly, now trying to attract banks and financial institutions with data-crunching and anti-money-laundering software. Techie employees kept happy with lucrative perks like child-care centers, Olympic-size swimming pool, 35-hour workweek, free soda and candy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned family’s wholesale business in Kolkata into Sun Pharmaceuticals in 1983. It’s now India’s fifth-largest drug company, of which he owns 72%. Grew through  acquisitions and alliances, including one with Detroit, Mich.-based generics company Caraco Pharm Labs, in which it has a large stake. Recently raised $350 million for more purchases. Sun’s rising stock turned Shanghvi into a billionaire last April; has cooled a bit due to new law that recognizes product patents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Palo Alto residential broker in the 1960s branched into commercial market. Now one of Silicon Valley’s largest commercial landlords, with more than 10 million square feet. Son, John Michael, runs the business day to day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Farm boy from Frankfort, Ky. inspired by radio reports of Charles Lindbergh’s transatlantic flight. Paid for flying lessons by opening hamburger stand near school. Dropped out of college, flew for Pan Am. Launched pilot training school FlightSafety International in 1951. Took public 1968. Sold to Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway in 1996. Now chairs Orbis International: nonprofit group uses airplanes as mobile ophthalmological labs for doctors in developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton grad and Harvard M.B.A. did whirlwind tour through upper ranks of Procter & Gamble, Keds, Hasbro, FTD Florists, Bain & Co., Disney before landing at the helm of online market-place Ebay in 1998. Led company through Internet shakeout, oversaw growth by securing loyal trading community. Took company global with services in Europe, Asia, Australia, Latin America. Last year purchased online classifieds business with 25% stake in popular Craigslist.com. Offline, “Meg” spends time fly-fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother of Dirk and Robert Ziff (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr., built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating), sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG. Och-Ziff Capital Management Group hedge fund group manages $8 billion in assets between four funds; OZ Multi-Strategy Fund up 41% in 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of the Ayala group, one of the country’s largest and oldest conglomerates, with a presence in numerous sectors of the Philippine economy, including telecom, real estate, banking and water, among others. The group was founded in 1834 by the original Ayala family, who came from Spain. The family just celebrated being in business for 170 years, and thus surviving two world wars, foreign occupation and Asia’s 1998 financial crisis. Jaime’s sons Jaime junior and Fernando, the seventh generation of Ayalas to run the group, took over daily operations from their father a decade ago. Stock of the family’s two main holdings, Ayala Corp. and Ayala Land, are both up more than 60% over last year thanks to improved results.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2001 Zyuzin’s Yuzhny Kuzbass (coal mines and coal trading) bought a controlling stake in Chelyabinsk Metallurgical Plant from commodity trader Marc Rich’s Glencore. From these assets Zyuzin created Mechel Group, the largest producer of specialty steel and alloys in Russia, which went public last year on the New York Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started off reselling scrap metal. Thirty years later heads $1.3 billion (sales) Vedanta Resources, a metals and mining company. Vedanta has profited from India’s privatization policies. Recently picked up state-owned Bharat Aluminum and Hindustan Zinc on the cheap. Profits climbed after Vedanta slashed jobs and curbed energy costs. Past 15 months have been a roller coaster: Successfully listed Vedanta on the London Stock Exchange in 2003 but event brought out critics who alleged he had misrepresented the company’s assets; the stock dropped. It has since rebounded, thanks to strong commodities markets.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Bernard Marcus (see), fired from now-defunct Handy Dan Home Improvement Centers in 1978, founded do-it-yourself category killer Home Depot. Took public 3 years later; now $65 billion in sales and still growing. Founders have hung up their tool belts but remain active: Marcus financing $200 million aquarium in Atlanta; Blank bought football’s Atlanta Falcons in 2002 for $545 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of pro football’s San Francisco 49ers severed ties to team in 1999 after splitting up shopping mall empire with sister Denise. Sister took the team; Eddie got large stake in Simon Property Group. University of Notre Dame grad tried to develop casinos, small card clubs; folded. Now tends to personal investment portfolio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Curtis, borrowed $55 in 1938 to produce trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Became Gold Bond Stamp Co. Diversified into hotels 1960s (Radisson Hotels & Resorts) and restaurants (T.G.I. Friday’s), travel agencies in 1970s. Renamed Carlson Cos. became travel-hospitality-marketing conglomerate: Radisson, Country Inns, Regent Hotels, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, Carlson-Wagonlit travel agencies. With sister Marilyn Nelson (see), inherited business after father’s death in 1999. Marilyn now the globetrotting chairman of $6.8 billion (sales) company. Overseeing major push into Asia. Barbara serves on the Carlson Cos. board of directors, runs family foundation, active with children’s charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband, John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995), parlayed $6,000 in gambling winnings into construction colossus. Took on high-risk projects: pipeline in South America, water supply in Abu Dhabi. Bought Kentucky, Tennessee coal reserves, sold to Amoco for stock during 1970s energy crisis. Son Raymond oversees family holdings; Marguerite hunts game on Georgia plantation.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the 1960s she and older sister Esther inherited construction giant Fomentos de Construcciones y Contratas, the company their father founded in 1944. In 1997 sold her shares to Esther for $800 million. Since then has been carefully investing in companies like Acerinox, Enagos, Banco Sabadel, Endesa, Inditex; also owns U.S. real estate and has stakes in hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal. A member of Spanish nobility (she holds the title of Marquesa de Bellavista), she has long been considered one of Spain’s most eligible women. But now rumor has it she is romantically linked to the Duque of Húescar, heir to the famous Spanish house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Al Lerner (d. 2002), Brooklyn-born immigrant’s son who built credit card giant MBNA, brought NFL back to Cleveland. Family still holds major stake in MBNA, though much reduced by taxman. Brother, Randy, chairman of MBNA, took over football’s Cleveland Browns after father’s death from cancer; mother Norma served briefly on MBNA board. Nancy, a former prosecuting attorney, now active in family’s real estate investments. Family keeps low profile, but active in educational, medical philanthropy in Cleveland area.
