name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad made first fortune selling contact-lens-design company to Cooper Labs for $60 million in 1971. Acquired New Jersey cable licenses; sold Vision Cable for $220 million in 1982. Later built cell phone business Metro Mobile, sold to Bell Atlantic for $2.6 billion 1992. With family now holds 28% of natural gas distributor Southern Union, large stake in Verizon Communications. Family of equestrians: son Adam an avid polo player; daughter Sloan competes in jumping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lucrative year for friendly biotech investor: sold Advanced Bionics (neurostimulation) to Boston Scientific for $4.1 billion last year (remains co-CEO); took biomed research outfit MannKind public in August 2004. Born to English father and Polish mother, started selling magazines, lemonade during the Depression. Earned physics master’s from UCLA. Founded, sold aerospace companies Spectrolab and Helioteck 1960s. Funded Pacesetter Systems (rechargeable pacemakers), MiniMed (insulin pumps); sold companies to Medtronic for $4.2 billion in 2001. Committed philanthropist says he’ll donate his entire fortune to charity and research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Curtis, borrowed $55 in 1938 to produce trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Became Gold Bond Stamp Co. Diversified into hotels 1960s (Radisson Hotels & Resorts) and restaurants (T.G.I. Friday’s), travel agencies in 1970s. Renamed Carlson Cos. became travel-hospitality-marketing conglomerate: Radisson, Country Inns, Regent Hotels, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, Carlson-Wagonlit travel agencies. Daughters inherited business after father’s death in 1999. Marilyn now the globetrotting chairman of $6.8 billion (sales) company. Overseeing major push into Asia. Sister, Barbara Gage (see), serves on the Carlson Cos. board of directors, runs family foundation, active with children’s charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Powerful wife of Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov started out as a factory worker, then entered the Moscow Institute of Management. Met Luzhkov in 1987 when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. In 1991 she started plastics-products company Inteko, which initially produced furniture and crockery but has since expanded into construction. The outfit is said to control as much as 20% of the city’s construction market. Now getting a jump on the vacation-home market in the resort town of Sochi.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief of Sodexho, a catering, facilities management and river cruise company. In 2000 an accounting scandal spurred profit warnings. Chaos continued to reign last year with the resignations of three executives running the U.K. division, including Bellon’s son Francois-Xavier, who left for medical reasons. In 2003 three people died from an outbreak of E. coli at a California retirement community, possibly relating to  spoiled spinach provided by Sodexho. That incident prompted a lawsuit by victims’ families and a settlement. It’s no wonder Bellon announced his retirement, effective September 2005, though he will remain busy as board chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of the Evergreen Group, a large transportation group based in Taiwan with major shipping and aviation interests. Evergreen’s history dates back to 1968 when it operated small ships to transport cargo. Today it has a fleet of 100 container vessels and ranks as one of the world’s largest shipping companies. Last summer it announced plans to order more ships. The group’s two airlines, EVA and Uniair, are facing competition from discount carriers but recently were allowed to operate the first passenger flights in 50 years from Taiwan to mainland China for the Lunar New Year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Clash of the egos as he pits his reality TV show, The Benefactor, against Donald Trump’s. Trump may have the ratings, but Cuban gets more screen time handing out challenges, deciding who merits a $1 million reward. Sold Internet broadcasting outfit Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion; shrewdly collared Yahoo stock before tech bust. Used windfall to buy Dallas mansion, Gulfstream jet, pro basketball’s Dallas Mavericks. Passionate owner eschews tinted-glass luxury box for courtside seats; racked up $1 million in fines for verbally abusing game officials, among other things. With Todd Wagner (see) invested in 2929 Entertainment: high-definition television network HDNet, art-house chain Landmark Theaters and Rysher Entertainment, which owns real estate. Perhaps the only member of The Forbes 400 to blog (www.blogmaverick.com).

name: Billionaires
bio: With pal David Geffen (see), cut teeth in fabled mailroom of Hollywood’s William Morris Agency. A media darling ever since: in the movie business (Paramount, under Michael Eisner), in television (ABC, Fox, USA Networks), now the Internet. Claims he became an e-commerce acolyte after watching Diane von Furstenberg sell clothes online; later married her. Now runs InterActiveCorp, growing blend of Internet sites: travel  (Expedia.com, Hotels.com), personal (LendingTree.com, Match.com), entertainment (Ticketmaster.com). Shrewd negotiator, personally reaped $275 million when NBC bought his old TV assets from Vivendi.

name: Billionaires
bio: The leader of Brazil’s largest retailer, Companhia Brasileira de Distribuicao, stepped down as chief executive in December 2002 but as chairman still goes to the office every day. The company has managed to hold its own against competition from global giants Wal-Mart and Carrefour. Diniz married for the third time last year, to a CBD executive some 35 years his junior. He stays fit by spending three hours a day playing squash and working out.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of PeopleSoft saw personal holdings jump after Oracle was given approval to buy his software manufacturer. Handed over day-to-day control to Oracle sales vet Craig Conway in 1999; remains chairman. Main diversion: overseeing the $150 million Maddie&#39s Fund (named after his late miniature schnauzer) to help make America a “no-kill” zone for unwanted pets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Returns to the billionaire ranks this year, thanks to a rebound in tourism. Opened his first hotel in Palma de Mallorca in 1956. Now his Sol Melia is the leading hotel company in Spain, Latin America and the Caribbean and ranks twelfth in the world. Properties include 350 hotels in 30 countries; has 24 hotels in Cuba. Still runs the company with help of two sons who work there. Avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former real estate developer Donald and wife, Doris (see,) founded Gap as a San Francisco jeans and music store in 1969. Six stores opened within first year. Pioneered customer convenience by arranging by size, not style. Now over 3,000 locations with expanded empire including Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986) and Old Navy (1994.) Last year, after 35 years running Gap, handed control of company, and nearly half their stock holdings, to their three sons.
title: Cofounder

name: Billionaires
bio: The billionaire jack-of-all-trades. While most of his wealth is tied up in the CFS Gandel Retail Trust, a $2.5 billion (market capitalization) real estate investment trust, Gandel also directly owns or shares ownership in two Australian shopping centers and five retirement villages. It all started when he inherited a woman&#39s clothing retailer from his parents, Polish immigrants who arrived in Melbourne just before World War II. Sold it in 1985 to his brother-in-law. Proceeds helped him develop Australia’s Priceline, a discount retailer of women&#39s cosmetics and beauty products. He and his wife collect Japanese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: After marrying daughter of salsamaker David Pace, worked way up from production line to president. With wife, bought out rest of family in 1982. Bought wife’s half for $95 million in 1991 divorce. Sold whole enchilada 4 years later to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion. Low-profile Texan invests in other food companies (Cider Jack hard cider, Ecce Panis bakeries) via private equity firm Silver Ventures.

name: Billionaires
bio: Emigrated from Israel as a child; raised in Michigan. Founded leveraged buyout firm Gores Technology Group 1987 after selling computers out of his father’s basement. Conglomerate now has 40 companies: The Learning Company (education software), Humanic Solutions (payroll, benefits systems), Pierce Technology (videoconferencing hardware). Bargain shopper: likes buying divisions of technology firms, rather than whole companies. Brother Tom (see) runs Platinum Equity; other brother, Sam, a Los Angeles talent agent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Mormon apartment caretakers got start managing hotel/gas station complex after college in Little America, Wyo. Bought 10% stake in operation, added stations in Utah, Arizona. Moved into refining as business grew; bought Sinclair Oil 1976. “Earl” diversified into hotels, including Sun Valley Ranch ski resort, home to Herb Allen’s (see) annual media mogul conference. Bought for $12 million, now worth over $300 million. Other resorts: Utah’s Snowbasin ski area and 395-suite Grand America Hotel, venues for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Salty-tongued tort lawyer still going strong. Penned autobiography, Trials and Jubilations; takes only one out of every 500 cases offered: “Mostly chickenshit stuff.” Started in D.A.’s office, formed own firm 1955. Built business on personal injury cases. Big score handling Texaco-Pennzoil merger 1987: received estimated $345 million in fees. Big donor to alma mater U. of Texas: “This country has enough roofers and car washers.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Media-shy fashion mogul got start selling newfangled motorcycle grips out of the trunk of his car in 1975. Added motorcycle goggles, sunglasses. Boosted sales through savvy marketing, new lens technology, instinct for style. Invaded Nike’s turf with push into sportswear, shoes. Introducing new shades outfitted with MP3 players. Reaped hundreds of millions selling Oakley shares in the 1990s; lately a buyer.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Berlin-born Harvard M.B.A. moved to Canada in 1949 and founded Montreal-based asset manager Jarislowsky, Fraser six years later. Firm manages $40 billion for pensions and high-net-worth individuals, up 25% from last year. Longtime minority shareholder advocate and founder of the Canadian Coalition for Good Governance, received embarrassing wrist-slap fine ($190,000) last year for advising clients in British Columbia without provincial registration. Used episode as platform to argue that Canada needs one regulatory body, like U.S.’ SEC, instead of 13 separate provincial ones. Eclectic collector: jade, Chinese furniture, Eskimo artifacts. Owns private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Gary Burrell while working as engineers at AlliedSignal. Struck out on their own 1989. Founded global positioning system equipment manufacturer Garmin (first 3 letters of each name). Manufactured digital navigation products and communication devices for boats, planes, hikers. Took public in 2000. Burrell recently retired; Kao serves as chairman and CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Shanghai and raised in Hong Kong, Lam studied engineering at National Taiwan University and went on to found one of the island's largest laptop computer maker, Quanta Computer. In addition to notebooks, his company now sells cellular phones and liquid crystal display televisions. In July he won a big-ticket order for 400,000 14-inch LCDs from Panasonic of Japan. More recently, was voted by thirtysomething male readers of a Taiwanese magazine one of the country's top five most admired men.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Hong Kong-based Shui On Construction and Materials Ltd. 34 years ago. Now one of the biggest sellers of such material in Hong Kong and mainland China. Recently founded Shui On Land to develop property in mainland China. Lo is involved in numerous high-profile business and government groups, including the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce. Also serves on several boards of Hong Kong and mainland Chinese companies including China Telecom Corp. Owns 20% of Riverside South, Trump’s project on New York City’s West Side. Comes from a well-connected family: His father, Lo Ying Shek, is chairman Great Eagle Holdings, a prominent Hong Kong property developer and hotel operator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold grocery distribution business to tennis partner Sam Walton for cash and Wal-Mart stock in 1990. Bought pro baseball’s Houston Astros. Moved team into new stadium 2000, renamed Minute Maid Park (formerly Enron Field); favorable lease lets team keep most of the revenue. Other ventures focus on logistics: exporting U.S. goods, revamping transportation for the military. Chairman of Baylor University’s board of regents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Honeywell exec became chief of data-routing powerhouse Cisco in 1988. Took public in 1990, increased sales hundredfold by focusing on the Internet; briefly the world's most valuable company. Stepped down as CEO in 1995, still maintains active role as chairman. Donates to technology education, alma maters Wisconsin and Stanford. Avid cyclist once bicycled across the U.S. with wife, Tashia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lottie, as she likes to be called, is the second-largest shareholder of successful Swedish clothing retail chain Hennes & Mauritz, founded by her father, Erling, in 1947 and now run by her brother Stefan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma, used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe in 1990, now the world’s fourth-largest producer of steel products. With fellow billionaire Rinat Akhmetov won a controversial $800 million bid in 2004 for Ukraine’s largest steel company, Kryvorizhstal. A Kiev court has ruled the sale illegal, but the two are appealing. Hosted dignitaries at Davos this year and is now working with Soros&#39 Renaissance Foundation and producing a documentary with Steven Spielberg on Ukraine’s Babi Yar massacre during World War II.

name: Billionaires
bio: The candymaker. For almost 60 years he and his brother Paul have owned and operated candy purveyor Haribo, best known for its Gummi Bears. Hans is credited with inventing more than 200 confections including the Gummi Bears, Maoam fruit chewies and Vademecum sugar-free gum; supposedly gets his inspiration from children’s television and comic books. Privately held concern has estimated $1.8 billion in sales. Childless, he is expected to be succeeded by one of his three nephews. He’s also a former German champion in badminton men’s doubles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college to flip burgers, eventually bought stakes in oil, real estate. Now owns 41 prime acres on the Las Vegas Strip, home to New Frontier hotel/casino. Land alone worth about $1 billion. Last year inked deal with friend Donald Trump to build 64-story Trump International Hotel & Tower. Still searching for partner to build 2 themed megaresorts on site. Other holdings: hotels in the Bahamas, convenience stores, hand-truck manufacturer Harper Truck. Continues legal push for slot machines at his 2 greyhound racetracks in Kansas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former top salesman for Oracle left 1990 after chief Larry Ellison (see) ditched plans to bring Siebel’s sales automation software to market. Founded Siebel Systems 1993; IPO 1996. Struggled through tech downturn, but regained footing in the rebound: Spent $70 million in 2003 to buy UpShot Corp. to run sales management software for client companies over the internet.

name: Billionaires
bio: The chief executive of $670 million (sales) Meriton Apartments joined the billionaires list for the first time in 2004, riding Sydney&#39s residential property boom and the strength of the Aussie dollar. His simple four-decade formula: Invest in low-cost, second-rate neighborhoods; offer low-cost, second-rate housing. But the boom peaked and started to downturn and Meriton sales were flat year over year. Born in China to Russian parents who fled the country during the Bolshevik Revolution, learned about real estate development as a child visiting his father, a builder, at work sites in Tientsin, China. Immigrated to Australia at age 14. Triguboff&#39s not worried, telling Forbes, “I think we’ve reached the bottom and will go up because there’s very little supply.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded an auto parts/repair company in 1985. Sold 80% of the company, Auto-Teile-Unger, to a British investor group in 2002 for an estimated $800 million. Received another estimated $360 million for the remaining 20% , when group was sold to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts last July.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former partner in Endemol, the Dutch TV production outfit credited with pioneering the reality show format with hits like Fear Factor and Big Brother. Earned billionaire status after the sale of Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefónica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. Today van den Ende chairs Stage Holding, a $760 million (sales) musical theater company—and Endemol spinoff—behind such Broadway megahits as Mamma Mia and 42nd Street. No doubt van den Ende is brushing up on his Spanish. Stage Holding has partnered with CIE, a Mexican live entertainment company, to produce musicals in Spain.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merchant Marine Academy grad took over family billboard business in 1946; sold for $960 million in 1998. Also veteran of lodging business; manages more than 90 Marriott hotels. Cheerful workaholic still exploiting new opportunities: apartments in Florida, Palm Springs, new billboard business in China. “I have been poor. Overall, rich is better.”

name: Billionaires
bio: The cofounder of Royal Caribbean recently ceded more control of the family finances to his three children, Arne Alexander, Bent Christian and Peter Preben. Alexander replaced him on Royal Caribbean’s board in 2003. While the cruise behemoth remains the tent pole of the family business, the Wilhelmsens have investments in real estate, tankers and international equities through Anders Wilhelmsen Group. Though an intensely private, loyal family, they have reportedly clashed with one another in past years about the allocation of the company&#39s assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Queen of all media renewed her contract last year, a move that will keep The Oprah Winfrey Show on the air through the 2010-11 season. Born in rural Mississippi. Moved to Milwaukee, then Tennessee. Miss Black Tennessee age 19. Became TV newscaster in Nashville, news anchor for ABC TV affiliate. After 9 months emotional, ad-lib delivery led to new position. Joined Chicago TV station; turned third-rated morning show to number one. Launched The Oprah Winfrey Show 1986. Now aired in 112 countries. After she recommended Anna Karenina, the 130-year-old Tolstoy novel jumped to top of New York Times bestseller list. Owns property in Hawaii, Santa Barbara. Gives to needy women, children and families via Oprah’s Angel Network and her personal charity, The Oprah Winfrey Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Detroit-born son of Greek immigrants, raised in Pasadena. Got real estate license 1962, bought and sold corner lots at busy intersections to gas stations. Moved to apartments 1968. Today Arnel & Affiliates real estate firm manages apartments, develops commercial property in southern California; also owns investment outfit Westar Capital. Ex-owner of baseball’s Seattle Mariners now ambassador to Spain. Planning return home following November election to spend more time with family.

name: Billionaires
bio: Upturn in oil and gas prices helping first family of Fort Worth overcome bad late-1990s tech bets. Oil-and-gas-exploration company getting ready to drill wells off the coast of Nova Scotia. Also owns stakes in Human Genome Sciences, John Wiley & Sons. Father and family patriarch, Perry, inherited slice of uncle Sid Richardson’s oil fortune after he died in 1951. Expanded empire. Handed family business to eldest son Sid in 1968, who brought in Stanford business school chum Richard Rainwater (see) in 1970. They engineered white knight Disney investment. Ed opted for Yale’s architecture school; built adobe homes in New Mexico and funded the now financially troubled Biosphere. Family responsible for revitalization of downtown Fort Worth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former loan processor, vending machine repairman invested in Silicon Valley commercial real estate with John Sobrato (see) in the 1960s. Struck out on own, formed Mission West Properties. Today some 8 million square feet in Silicon Valley, but lately dealing with vacancies. Better times tending to more than 100 technology investments, including Netlogic Microsystems, which went public in July.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father was trade attaché under Douglas MacArthur during World War II; founded sourcing and logistic business after the conflict. “Chip” started working at Asian-based William E. Connor & Associates at age 12; took over in early 1980s. Estimated sales: $1.6 billion. Half of business comes from apparel; the remainder from home products like furniture, lighting. Clients include Nordstrom, Saks Fifth Avenue, Dillard’s, Smithsonian and Harrods.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulent Eczacibasi makes cheap drugs—a lot of them. The unofficial czar of Turkey’s medical and pharmaceutical sector draws his family name from the honorary title of the nation’s head pharmacist bestowed on his grandfather 95 years ago. Recognized by elite European business group as one of Europe’s top 45 industrialists, Bulent has expanded the business founded by father, Nejat, who entered the drug business in 1952. Along with wife, Oya, Bulent was a major benefactor of Istanbul’s new Modern Art Gallery, one of the hip city’s newest artsy gathering posts. The couple received Foundation of Contemporary Arts Prize of Honor, Turkey’s most prestigious prize for visual arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother William runs family’s Hong Kong import-export firm Li & Fung. Company sources, exports for clients like Disney, Coca-Cola, Kohl’s. Became first wholly owned company to be granted an export license by the government of China. Victor earned engineering degree from MIT, business doctorate from Harvard. Recently signed licensing deal to design, manufacture and distribute clothing under Levi Strauss label.

name: Billionaires
bio: Managing director of Li & Fung, the global outsourcing company that supplies clothes and fashion accessories to retailers like Abercrombie & Fitch. Brother and fellow billionaire Victor is chairman. Looking for new prospects, the Fungs have struck licensing agreement with Levi Strauss & Co.; spun off group’s marketing and contract manufacturing unit, raising $ 54 million; may consider listing Toys “R” Us Asia franchise.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout had plenty of time to watch TV, didn’t like poor reception. Built own antenna tower with $1,500. Later built cable franchises. Sold Cablevision Industries to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion. Still owns big Time Warner stake; manages other investments via Granite Associates. In July broke ground on Bethel Woods project: music museum and amphitheater built on Max Yasgur’s Woodstock concert site. Grows corn and berries on 160-acre farm in Liberty.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built chain of arts-and-crafts stores from scratch, starting in 1972 with 1 store selling handmade wooden picture frames. Now 335 stores, estimated $1.3 billion in sales. Expands on the cheap, often by renovating empty big-box stores instead of building new. Low-tech retailer eschews bar codes, buying from wholesale suppliers; set up offices in China, Philippines to buy direct from factories. Devout Christian keeps stores closed on Sundays, supports churches and evangelical missions around the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Growing up in spacious homes and on private jets, Saad Hariri didn't get too spoiled to want to get his hands dirty at Saudi Oger, the $3.25 billion (sales) construction firm started by his dad, Rafik Hariri. Dealt a tragedy in February 2005 when billionaire Rafik was slain in Beirut. Now, at 34 the amateur scuba diver and avid mobile telecom investors has mandate from his family to steer the Saudi Oger ship from his base in Riyadh. The Georgetown University graduate's ties to Washington DC may loosen if family ratifies a contract to sell almost two dozen acres of land there to a Miami home developer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father founded first U.S. commercial airline, but it never got off the ground. Went into radio, built one of Minneapolis’ first stations (WAMD—“Where All Minneapolis Dances”); added television in 1948. Stanley took over Hubbard Broadcasting in 1981, pioneered satellite television news gathering. Took United States Satellite Broadcasting public 1996. Sold to Hughes/DirecTV in 1999 for $1.3 billion. Still owns 13 television, 4 radio stations. Children taking over the day-to-day control: “I’m the chairman and chief cheerleader.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather turned circus icon, Laliberte founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Laliberte eventually bought out his majority partner in 2000. Hit the jackpot in 1991 when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas. Today the $525 million (2004 revenues) group has four permanent shows in Sin City, including the $165 million Ka, which opened in February at MGM Grand. Produces a total of ten shows, with another three on the way. Next show in Vegas: Beatles-themed production at the Mirage; show will replace Siegfried & Roy. Known for lavish parties, Laliberte, who dreams of one day traveling into space, owns 95% of the company. Cirque donates 1% of sales to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Queens-born investment banker made small fortune taking Ross Perot’s Electronic Data Systems public in 1968. Made large fortune providing seed money for Home Depot. Landed in spotlight as defendant in N.Y. Attorney General Eliot Spitzer’s lawsuit over pay package awarded to former NYSE chief Richard Grasso. Staunchly defends his role as chair of Big Board’s compensation committee; penned withering editorial against Spitzer, NYSE board member and Goldman Sachs Chief Hank Paulson. Refuses to settle; claims case will never come to trial.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable LBO titan finally putting to work the $6.1 billion raised in 2001. Led a consortium of investors, including Edgar Bronfman Jr., in $2.6 billion purchase of Warner Music; rumored public offering already in the works. Other recent deals: financial services outfit Refco Group for $2.3 billion, Nortek (oven ranges) for $1.6 billion and Better Foods for $1.1 billion. Harvard grad started investing with $150,000 inheritance 1974. Early success with Sterling Jewelers: bought for $28 million in 1985, sold 2 years later for $210 million. Then Snapple: bought for $135 million 1992; sold to Quaker Oats for $1.7 billion in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Red” owns big stake in Clear Channel Communications, the radio outfit started with Lowry Mays (see) in 1972. Also owns Toyota, Ford car dealerships, investments in oil, real estate. Agreed to sell his Minnesota Vikings pro football team. Took 25% stake in Internet guitar merchants J.R. Beck, now out of business. Fighting environmentalists for right to develop Colorado wilderness area into luxury ski resort.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a respected Soviet physicist, Melnichenko studied physics at the prestigious Moscow State University. Dropped out in 1991 and together with some schoolmates, sold computers, established a chain of currency-exchange booths; in 1993 founded MDM Bank. It later handled the accounts of oil tycoon Roman Abramovich and other businessmen then favored by the Kremlin. In 2000, after a failed attempt to sign up the Ministry of Atomic Energy as a client, Melnichenko teamed up with metals trader Sergei Popov and began accumulating an industrial empire that now includes chemicals, coal mines, steel mills and a 6% stake in Russia's electric monopoly.

name: Billionaires
bio: Largely unknown until a few years ago, Popov is co-owner of the MDM Group. Studied to be an ordinary electrical engineer but left the field to go into business. Throughout the 1990s he made his way through the murky world of metals and oil trading in the Urals and Siberia. As a client of MDM Bank, he got to know the bank's owner, Andrei Melnichenko. After the collapse of the ruble in 1998 he convinced Melnichenko to buy up Russian steel mills, chemical companies and coal mines on the cheap. As the chairman of the board at MDM Group, Popov handled the group's industrial assets. Last year the shareholders dissolved MDM Group, dividing its various interests into separate holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandchild of Richard Beatty Mellon, founder of T. Mellon & Sons, predecessor of Mellon Bank. Philanthropist and publisher; controls conservative Pittsburgh Tribune-Review as well as radio stations in western Pennsylvania. Supports conservative institutions including Heritage Foundation. Investor in NewsMax, conservative news Web site and magazine that abandoned plans for public offering last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Civil engineer became head of Omaha construction firm Kiewit in 1979. Moved company into telecom, fiber optics, power plants. Retired as Kiewit chairman but still chairs Level 3 Communications. Sits on board of Berkshire Hathaway.

name: Billionaires
bio: This onetime partner at Brazilian investment bank Banco Garantia helped build AmBev into the world’s third-largest brewer by volume, with 70% of the Brazilian beer market. Last year Interbrew of the Netherlands merged with AmBev, creating powerhouse brewer InBev. Telles, cochairman of AmBev, was one of the biggest beneficiaries, along with two former Garantia partners and AmBev controlling shareholders, Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira. Telles is reportedly a keen spearfisher and spends much of his time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate. Bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. His $640 million (sales) Olav Thon Gruppen now own 18 properties abroad and 320 in Norway, including shopping malls and office buildings, 41 hotels and several restaurants and pubs in Oslo. Even makes raw ingredients for soap and cosmetics.

name: Billionaires
bio: It can’t get too cold for Viessmann, whose $1.4 billion (2003 sales) company makes boilers and heating equipment. Viessmann owns 100% of the group founded by his grandfather in 1917. Company sponsors Austrian Formula One racing car driver, Niki Lauda. Operates the Viessmann Academy, which trains heating architects and engineers. Other activities: He’s president of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce; treasurer of Marburg University; holds a professional pilot’s license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hired hand from small Tennessee town took over medical supply company founded in 1941 by Homer Stryker. Turned niche manufacturer of hospital beds into dominant medical device manufacturer. Sales: $3.6 billion. Recent acquisition of SpineCore, maker of artificial lumbar and cervical discs, should provide the backbone for continued growth.

name: Billionaires
bio: World’s biggest mining promoter now busy in Mongolia. Chicago-born, made first fortune after stumbling onto one of the world’s biggest nickel deposits while searching for diamonds in Voisey’s Bay, Newfoundland. Sold Diamond Fields Resources in 1996 for $3.1 billion. “Toxic Bob” now touting copper and gold deposits discovered in Mongolia by his NYSE-listed Ivanhoe Mines.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical doctor founded Hospital Corp. of America with father in 1968. Took public 1969; owned 51 hospitals by 1973. Merged with Columbia Healthcare in 1994. Now nation’s largest for-profit hospital operator with 281 hospitals and outpatient surgery centers. Came out of retirement to help revive company during a lengthy Medicare-fraud investigation. But still ailing: HCA stock down 8% this year. Transferred 75% of his HCA holdings to his children and grandchildren. “If I died tomorrow, they won’t pay any taxes.” Brother Bill Frist is U.S. Senate majority leader.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall magnate, owner of pro football’s 2003 Super Bowl champs Tampa Bay Buccaneers spent the past year increasing stake in England’s premier soccer club, Manchester United, prompting speculation he’s looking to take over team. Rochester native worked in father’s watch shop at age 8, handed reins at 15. Invested in mobile-home parks, restaurants, real estate. Major stakeholder in Zapata, onetime oil-and-gas company, now a holding company. Maker of air-bag fabric and marine protein for animal feed.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Payroll-processing salesman recognized market serving small businesses. Started Paychex in 1971 with $3,000. Expanded through franchise agreements, joint ventures. Consolidated company in 1979, took public 1983. Now 100 offices, 
$1.1 billion in sales. Founded New York’s Independence political party; personally financed 3 unsuccessful runs for governor. Owner of pro hockey’s Buffalo Sabres, also supports colleges and hospital in hometown Rochester.

name: Billionaires
bio: Early investor in Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway flew under the radar until joining board in 2003. Harvard M.B.A. founded investment advisory firm First Manhattan in 1964. Sits on board of American Museum of Natural History.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of Maruhan Corp., the largest chain of pachinko parlors in Japan with 166 parlors nationwide. Maruhan's sales have more than tripled in the past 5 years. This year should prove stellar if Han is able to take Maruhan public, perhaps single-handedly revamping the image of an industry notorious for tax evasion and mafia ties. Pachinko is a $30 billion a year industry in Japan, with pachinko machine makers more visible on the capital markets. Maruhan is poised to become the first pachinko parlor chain to be listed in the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: West Virginia-born numbers geek completed math and physics degrees from Harvard in 3 years 1949. Started as actuarial trainee at Occidental Life making $225 a month; saw sales guys made more. Started own property and casualty shop. Founded Mercury General in 1962, targeted customers having trouble getting auto insurance. Focused on personal, noncommercial vehicles; aggressively investigated suspicious claims. Took public 1985; now California’s 3rd-largest auto insurer with $3 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners, John Herma and Jay Baker, took over Kohl’s department store chain in 1986 management buyout. Rapidly expanded 40-store chain, took public in 1992. Today 600 Kohl’s stores generate $10 billion in sales, but stock lately losing ground because of ballooning inventories, increased competition. Stepped down as CEO 1999; keeps eye on small investment in used car chain CarMax.

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger son of the venerated Li Ka-shing. Borrowed $250 million from his father and launched StarTV in 1991; later sold the satellite TV operation to Rupert Murdoch for $950 million. Used proceeds to start Pacific Century Group, with interests in real estate, financial services and technology. In January his PCCW raised $1 billion in share sales to China Netcom, the largest-ever equity investment by a Chinese company in Hong Kong. Li is a licensed pilot and scuba divemaster.

name: Billionaires
bio: After a yearlong, six-way bidding war Sir Kenneth emerged the winner of Safeway supermarkets, agreeing to pay $5 billion in stock and cash. The deal, completed in March 2004, ups his Morrisons supermarket’s share of the U.K. grocery market to 16%, making it the fourth largest grocery. Morrisons’ stock suffered a 30% loss in the six months following the completion of the buyout but has now recovered.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner, Peter May, runs publicly traded buyout firm Triarc. Wharton dropout made famous with Michael Milken-assisted acquisitions of Triangle Industries 1983, National Can 1985. Sold conglomerate 5 years later for $830 million profit. More success: bought Snapple in 1997 for $300 million from Quaker Oats, sold 3 years later for $1.5 billion. Arby’s owner lost bid for Burger King in 2002, remains on the prowl for new deals with $700 million war chest.

name: Billionaires
bio: Tough money manager learned finance as a $200-a-week research assistant under Max Heine (d. 1988). Earned reputation for buying undervalued companies, raising hell: tussled with management of companies held in his portfolios. Sold Heine Securities in 1996 to Franklin Resources for $670 million and lucrative 5-year employment contract. Now runs MFP Investors; owns stakes in Dow Jones, Dillards, Edward Lampert’s (see) Kmart Holdings. Avid polo player serves on board of NYC’s Jazz at Lincoln Center with money man Tom Lee (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2003 sales: $5.5 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (207 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama includes Robert’s two youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, living with his ex-wife. Liesel and Matthew filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family has offshore trusts. Case recently settled.  Nicholas runs Hyatt Development.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Vietnam vet’s Majestic Realty the largest commercial builder in Los Angeles with 55 million square feet of space. In Las Vegas developing 400-acre business park off Sin City’s new beltway with Thomas & Mack; company controls 3 million square feet in the gambling mecca. Built Staples Center with Philip Anschutz (see); duo made failed attempt to bring pro football back to Los Angeles. USC grad loves sports: minority owner of pro basketball’s L.A. Lakers, hockey’s 
L.A. Kings. Other vice: antique sports cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman of Sabanci Group, one of Turkey’s biggest conglomerates, spends as much time in London as he does in Istanbul. Brother Sakip held the reins until his 2004 death. Sevket lets his relatives handle daily operations while he keeps his perch on the board. Spent $1 million building a park in Bodrum, Turkey, naming it after himself. Other past charitable activities included the Çatalhöyük Research Project, an archeological site in Turkey first excavated in the 1960s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Recently built largest top-class office space in California’s San Joaquin County. Helipad on top for Spanos’ use. Son Dean heads pro football’s San Diego Chargers. Trying to win a deal with city officials for a new stadium; pledged $200 million to make it happen. New lease with San Diego dispels rumors that he’s moving team to Los Angeles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a bartender, raised in Illinois projects. Paid way through college selling life insurance, working construction jobs. Started Excel Communications, multilevel marketer of long-distance service. Sold to Teleglobe for $3.5 billion in 1998. Budding equestrian owns WinStar Farm in Kentucky, state-of-the-art Thoroughbred breeding and training grounds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance invented soup-condensing process while working at uncle’s Campbell Preserve Co. Bought out uncle in 1914. Weber inherited Campbell stake from one of John&#39s daughters. Sits on Campbell board. Horse enthusiast gives to Philadelphia-area philanthropy, collects art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold popcorn outside dad’s Minnesota barbershop. UCLA on hockey scholarship; Harvard M.B.A., night law school at Loyola. Cofounded of Kindel & Anderson law firm 1953; learned beverage distribution business from clients. Formed distributor Ace Beverage 1956, landed exclusive rights to distribute then-minor beer brand Budweiser in Los Angeles. Today oversees Topa Equities: car dealerships (Silver Star Automotive), insurance, real estate (more than 1 million square feet of commercial space in L.A.). Active octogenarian still occasionally spotted driving his Subaru.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sydney (d. 1971), ran family’s shoemaking business. Ed preferred media. Bought first TV station in Miami in 1962 for $3.4 million; added Boston station in 1993. Also real estate. Sunbeam Development, headed by son Andrew owns more than 4 million square feet of commercial space, much of it in Broward County, Fla. Ed a big donor to United Way.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners Richard Peery (see), became 2 of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Lifelong partners shun debt, the media. Arrillaga a big donor to alma mater Stanford University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iraqi-born Londoner once was member of the infamous Ba’ath Party though he claims Saddam Hussein murdered his two brothers. Now sees Iraqi action on multiple fronts: his General Mediterranean Holding holds 36% of Mid Contracting, a Jordan-based construction firm that is doing work in Iraq. Auchi also owns 6.5% of Orascom Telecom Holding, an Egyptian firm that won the bid for setting up cell phone service in Iraq.

name: Billionaires
bio: If he has his way, don’t look for Emilio Azcárraga Jean on the list of Mexican billionaires for too much longer: The scion of Spanish-language media empire Grupo Televisa is reportedly looking to become a U.S. citizen. That would enable the 37-year-old Televisa chief executive to circumvent FCC rules prohibiting foreigners from owning more than 25% of a broadcast network. Televisa currently owns an 11% stake in Univision, which broadcasts soap operas, sporting events and game shows to the 30 million Spanish-speaking people in the United States. Azcárraga Jean has indicated he wants a bigger stake. Last spring he is said to have paid $4.2 million for a luxurious Miami Beach home in the gated Sunset Island neighborhood—neighbors include rocker Lenny Kravitz and singer Enrique Iglesias—and some speculate that Azcárraga Jean’s purchase is the first step in his plan to becoming a full-fledged U.S. citizen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State University graduate stepped down as chairman of scandal-tainted Janus, mutual fund company he started in 1969 with money borrowed from his mom. Company fund managers accused of ripping off investors via market timing; firm finalized $100 million settlement with regulators in August. Bailey sold stake to Stilwell Financial for $600 million in 2002; Janus now led by former Charles Schwab exec Steven Scheid.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Judd Malkin, ran powerhouse JMB Realty during 1980s, eventually managed $26 billion in office buildings, shopping malls, apartments, hotels. Market pummeled 1990s; stuck it out, now enjoying rising values. Developing Niagara Falls casino with Pritzker family (see). Controls Four Seasons hotels in Chicago, Scottsdale, Ariz. Last year the longtime Democrat hosted rally for U.S. Senate hopeful Barack Obama at his home.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fulbright scholar, Ph.D. in electrical engineering from MIT launched Bose Corp. in 1964. First contracts with NASA, U.S. military, but brand built on innovative loudspeaker design. Introduced first factory-installed car stereo system in 1982; today a major supplier for high-end automobiles (Porsche, Mercedes). Latest effort: developing a new car-suspension system.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth generation of Bruchs to run $5.2 billion (revenues) Globus & Co. KG. Under his watch, the 177-year-old company has developed into Germany’s 11th-largest food retailer. With a sixth generation of Bruchs waiting in the wings (he has three sons), continued family stewardship seems assure.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former auto repair shop owner, John Caudwell entered the cell phone business in 1987. In his first eight months, he sold just 26 phones from his store in hardscrabble Stoke-on-Trent. The next year’s sales: $1.5 million—a figure that doubled in size every year until 1995. Last year his 350 stores in the United Kingdom and other telecommunications businesses brought in an estimated $70 million on $3.4 billion, while Caudwell doled out $1.85 million bonuses to top staff and continued his blanket ban on employee emails. In his spare time, he completed an 18-day, 2,300-mile bike ride from Athens to London to raise $500,000 for his trust, which gives money to charities helping sick, disabled and terminally ill children.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners Alijan Ibragimov and Alexander Mashkevitch built up an industrial empire in the most unlikely of places, Kazakhstan. Their $5 billion (estimated sales) Eurasia Group includes a number of enterprises like Kazakhstan Mineral Resources Corporation and Kazchrome; also a construction company and bank. Group has recently benefitted from booming Kazakh economy, rising commodity prices and soaring exports to China. A native of Uzbekistan, Chodiev is now a citizen of Kazakhstan and Belgium.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Procter & Gamble product manager created Quicken's personal finance software in 1983 to help wife balance checkbook. Shipped first commercial copy 1 year later. Today Intuit software products include tax preparation, small-business bookkeeping. Avid cyclist funds business school product management program at University of Wisconsin, his wife's alma mater.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turkey’s resident Rupert Murdoch, Dogan’s media empire owns the largest newspaper and television properties. Influential in Turkey if for no other reason than 60% of nationwide ad revenues flow to his firm. He acquired the daily Milliyet in 1979 after a career as a commodity trader. The non-English speaker can rely on his four daughters, two of whom boast M.B.A.s from Columbia Business School, to negotiate with U.S. media brands. Fittingly, his eponymous charitable foundation supports education and programs to wipe out illiteracy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boating enthusiast started first marine business in 1955. Built into Bayliner Marine Corp. Sold to Brunswick for $425 million in 1986. Reinvested in stocks, bonds, Arizona real estate. Partner in Westport Shipyard, builder of luxury yachts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ford family patriarch brought company back under family control after installing son Bill Jr. as Ford chief in 2001. Brought back profits, but stock still lagging. Next-generation Ford bucking Motor City tradition with plans for hybrid cars, push for higher gas tax. But hasn’t completely abandoned the past: introducing new version of company’s classic Mustang. Bill Sr., grandson of Henry Ford, spends retirement watching his Detroit Lions pro football team playing in new $350 million Ford Field.

name: Billionaires
bio: World’s biggest bond trader got start gambling. Psychology major at Duke arranged fraternity poker tournaments. Spent summers as a slots manager at Harrah’s in Lake Tahoe; never gambled, slept in car, bathed in lake to save money. Started playing blackjack in Las Vegas after graduation 1966; turned $200 into $10,000 in four months. Joined Navy, served in Vietnam. Moved to Los Angeles, got M.B.A from UCLA 1971, took $11,000 securities-analyst position at insurance giant Pacific Life. Discovered how to make money with bonds: trade, don’t buy and hold. Handed $10 million portfolio to manage 1973. Stellar returns made him a superstar; earned $20 million bonuses in the  1980s. Bond division spun off to create Pimco. Company went public 1994, then sold to German insurance giant Allianz AG for $4.7 billion in 2000; personally made more than $400 million. Current Pimco chief investment officer. Annual salary: $40 million. Flagship Pimco Total Return Fund up 9.7% a year since 1987; $76 billion in assets. Hard worker: wakes up each morning at 3 a.m. to monitor Asian markets. Prince Charming: kept second-wife-to-be in the dark about wealth until they were engaged.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of coffee magnate Max Herz. Has had to watch as her five children fight over her deceased husband’s legacy, management of German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding. In 2003 two children cashed out. Then earlier this year a third was unexpectedly voted off the supervisory board. Still holds a 15% stake in the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Travel is back. And so is Barron Hilton, after 5-year hiatus from The Forbes 400. Son of Hilton Hotels founder, Conrad, joined company 1951 as elevator operator, became chairman in 1979. Sold pro football’s San Diego Chargers to invest in casinos. Investment in Caesars Entertainment riding high with Vegas boom, but sex-symbol granddaughter Paris Hilton steals all the headlines.

name: Billionaires
bio: A native Uzbek, began his career as a director of a wool-processing factory before moving on to run a plastics firm. In 1991 partnered with Patokh Chodiev and Alexander Mashkevich to found Eurasia Group, now one of Kazakhstan’s most successful companies. The $5 billion (estimated sales) company has interests in aluminum, chromium, coal, construction and banking. Has operations in South Africa and offices in Brussels and London. Group has recently benefitted from booming Kazakh economy, rising commodity prices and soaring exports to China. His two oldest sons have joined the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Louis, opened popcorn stand in 1915, grew into major sports concessions business. Jeremy took over company after father’s death, transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. Runs concessions at major ballparks, airports, visitor centers at national parks. Recently purchased Tenaya Lodge, destination resort near Yosemite National Park; Harrison Hot Springs & Spa in British Columbia. Bought bankrupt Mississippi River cruise-ship company Delta Queen in 2002. Owns Boston’s Fleet Center, pro hockey’s Boston Bruins. Avid horseman created equestrian sanctuary on 400 acres near Wellington, Fla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Played football at the University of Arkansas. Joined father’s insurance business 1965 after getting M.B.A. Bought pro football’s Dallas Cowboys and stadium for $140 million in 1989. Continues to invest in real estate, oil and gas, but “95% of my time is with the Dallas Cowboys. We are going to turn around on the field.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Memphis-born cotton trader turned hedge fund manager hasn’t had a down year since he started Tudor Investment; firm has posted 26% average annual returns since 1986. Plans to expand operations into Asia, bulk up staff in Europe. Early success: predicted 1987 market crash, turned prescient short positions into 200% gains. “You adapt, evolve, compete or die.” Avid pheasant hunter, bass fisherman owns property around the world, including getaways in Florida Keys, Zimbabwe. Dedicated philanthropist founded New York City’s poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: An original investor in $1.6 billion (sales) Amdocs, a customer relationship management and billing software firm for large telecom outfits. (One out of every two phone calls made in North America relies on Amdocs software.) Has cashed out more than $900 million worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998. He’s also a part-owner of Aurec Group, an Israeli-based private equity firm with cable and telecom investments. The press-shy former diver founded Coral World International, a string of aquariums in Eilat, Israel; Maui; and Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: This art dealer has amassed one of the world's largest collections of Islamic art, including particularly fine examples of rare Koranic manuscripts. The Islamic collection is comprised of over 20,000 objects and spans some 1,400 years. Khalili also collects Japanese art of the Meiji period, Indian and Swedish textiles, Spanish damascened metalwork and Russian enamels. Left Iran before the 1979 revolution and is now a dual U.S.-British citizen. Lives in tony Mayfair section of London with wife Marion and their three sons. Charitable activities include soccer league for Jewish and Muslim youth. On the horizon: perhaps a permanent home for his art treasures in central London (A plan to loan to British government fell through in the mid-1990s.)

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean immigrant came to U.S. to start American marketing arm of father's small Korean chipmaker Anam Semiconductor. Stateside company Amkor Technology eventually became bigger, bought many of Anam's factories during Asian financial crisis. Stock lately a roller coaster: lost 90% of its value in 2002. With family owns big stake in Electronics Boutique, retail chain started by wife, Agnes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once celebrated for his wealth and entrepreneurial successes, now shunned. A special parliamentary commission is investigating whether Kulczyk, who has a stake in the government-controlled oil giant Orlen, met with a Russian spy to discuss the sale of Orlen to the Russians, and is looking at murky ties between him and leading politicians. Kulczyk has denied wrongdoing. Political ties appeared to help early on. In the early 1990s he won a government contract to deliver cars for Poland’s police and Office of State Protection. And in 1993 he bought a stake in a previously state-owned brewery for $10 million that’s now worth an estimated $500 million. Also has investments in Hungarian oil company MOL and in various financial services companies. When asked by the parliamentary committee about his fortune, Kulczyk said: "I don’t want to talk about things which I don’t know exactly."

name: Billionaires
bio: With his partners Patokh Chodiev and Alijan Ibragimov controls $5 billion (estimated sales) Eurasia Group, a Kazakhstan-based company with interests in aluminum, chromium, coal, construction and banking. Expanding into new markets including South Africa. Group has recently benefitted from booming Kazakh economy, rising commodity prices and soaring exports to China. A former university professor in Kirgizstan. Is also an Israeli citizen and a member of the World Jewish Congress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of cable giant TCI. Inherited big stake in TCI, massive legal headaches. Settled differences with father&#39s second wife, Sharon, and right-hand man John Malone, but now busy sorting out estate of recently deceased elder brother, Kim. Recent 50th birthday celebration included performance by pop diva Jessica Simpson, arranged by wife, Sarah Siegel, designer of So Low line of women’s underwear.

name: Billionaires
bio: The frothy stock market tripled the value of his shares in French telecom Alcatel, which in 1999 bought his Newbridge Networks for $7 billion. His two latest ventures,  Ottawa-based Mitel and March Networks, develop Internet telephony and video applications. Not surprisingly, they’re deep in the red, though Matthews has hopes for an IPO. Wales-born Matthews owns lavish golf resort Celtic Manor there. With 400 rooms and three courses, it’s slated to host the famed Ryder Cup in 2010. Back in Ottawa, his new upscale Brookstreet Hotel boasts 276 rooms—and even serves as a ready-made testing ground for his companies’ telecom products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mérieux, chief executive of biotech outfit BioMérieux, joins the elite billionaire ranks following his company’s successful IPO in July 2004. In 1897 his father Marcel, a former laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur, formed Institut Mérieux, now part of Sanofi-Aventis.  BioMérieux specializes in in-vitro diagnostics and the diagnosis of infectious diseases. Eldest son, Rondolphe, the intended successor, was tragically killed in TWA Flight 800 in 1996. As a result Mérieux’s 35-year-old son Christophe, a doctor, is poised to take the reins within three years.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Tel Aviv-born movie mogul responsible for megahits like Pretty Woman and L.A. Confidential founded New Regency Productions in 1991. The company enjoyed a $1.7 billion windfall last year from the sale of its stake in sportswear maker Puma. Milchan’s own background is the stuff of movies. A former biochemistry student and soccer player, he successfully transformed his family’s fledgling fertilizer company into a multimillion-dollar chemicals business. Parlayed that into a role as an arms dealer for Israel, which he coyly discussed in a 60 Minutes interview in 2000. (Milchan denies he was an arms dealer but admits to acting as an intermediary between the country and defense contractors like Raytheon.) Began bankrolling films for directors Sergio Leone and Martin Scorsese. Counts among his close friends Shimon Peres, Rupert Murdoch and Robert De Niro. .

name: Billionaires
bio: Junk-bond guru joined Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1969; fueled 1980s leveraged buyout boom. Salary, bonus $550 million in 1986 alone. Wharton M.B.A. ratted out by arbitrager Ivan Boesky; pled guilty to 6 counts of securities fraud. Paid $900 million settlement to government, litigators, creditors; served 22 months in prison. Dedicated philanthropist and prostate cancer survivor created Center for Accelerating Medical Solutions, a Washington, D.C. think tank. Big backer of education: $25,000 checks to 100 exceptional teachers and principals every year. Holding company Knowledge Universe has day care centers (Knowledge Universe Learning Corp.), private schools (Nobel Learning Communities), educational toys (LeapFrog).

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 50% of $1.5 billion (sales) Storck GmbH, makers of some of Germany’s most popular candies (Toffifee, Merci, Riesen, nimm2, Werther’s Original). Inherited Storck from father, Klaus, on the occasion of the company’s 100th birthday in June 2003. His two sisters and his brother, Tim Oberwelland (a Hollywood movie producer whose credits include Simpatico with Nick Nolte and Jeff Bridges) were bought out. Unsuccessfully tried to trademark the original shape of Werther’s Original candies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Banking baron Husnu left Turkey after high school with $1,000 and traveled by boat to enroll at Oregon State University. (Prior to that he was boarding school bunkmate of controversial fellow Turk banking magnate, and former billionaire, Mehmet Karamehmet.) Picked up an M.B.A. from Harvard rather than follow footsteps of his doctor father. Wise choice: Ozyegin’s Finansbank, seeded with $2.5 million of capital, became the first bank in Turkey to do subordinated debt. It now ranks as the country’s fifth-largest private bank by consolidated assets. Helps finance other firms’ receivables through his Fiba Holding subsidiaries. Fluent in English and a proud papa of his well-schooled children, Ozyegin claims to be part of the first Turkish dad-son graduating pair from Harvard Business School.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga (see) became 2 of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Lifelong partners shun debt, the media. Arrillaga a big donor to alma mater Stanford University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Joseph, ran pharmacy in Brooklyn. Stewart took over after dropping out of law school, turned into generic drug distributor Kinray: over $3 billion in sales. Recently bought East Hampton, N.Y. estate for $45 million, but drives to work in 10-year-old Jeep Cherokee.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financier completed $4.5 billion sale of International Steel Group to Indian mogul Lakshmi Mittal in October. Cash and stock deal created world&#39s largest steel company; Ross built ISG buying up financially distressed U.S. steelmakers and putting them under one roof. Lawyer’s son started out parking cars at racetrack in Monmouth, N.J. Dreamed of being a writer; worked on literary magazine at Yale. Gave up after fiction class required writing 500 words a day; feared running out of material. Took summer job on Wall Street, refined research and analysis skills. Landed job at Rothschild 1976; as bankruptcy specialist cleaned up messes left by Drexel Burnham junk-bond financings. Began running private equity fund 1997, struck out on own 3 years later. Founded WL Ross & Co.: buys companies in tired industries like coal, steel, textiles; cleans up balance sheet, improves management, sells for profit quickly. Today manages about $3 billion in 7 private equity funds, 2 hedge funds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Not even Joanne Kathleen Rowling could have imagined the power her pubescent wizard possessed. The former welfare mother’s five Harry Potter books have sold 265 million copies. That number is sure to soar this summer, as Potter-philes are again expected to camp out in bookstores for the release of "Harry Potter and The Half-Blood Prince".  Potter movies have grossed almost over $3 billion, including DVDs,  with another DVD installment slated for release this fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: The widow of banker Edmond Safra makes regular appearances in the social pages both in London and the U.S., sometimes with granddaughter Lily Elia. Friends include Prince Charles and his fiancée, Camilla Parker Bowles. Under Lily’s direction the Edmond J. Safra Philanthropic Foundation gave $10 million last year to the Harvard University Center for Ethics and the Professions. She also sits on the board of the Michael J. Fox Foundation and has funded some of its genetics research grants.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns a third of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck. Brothers Dieter and Stefan von Holtzbrinck control the rest. Heads its S. Fischer Verlag unit, which dates back to 1886.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vocally pro-independent Taiwanese tycoon Shi Wen-long relinquished ties with the Chi Mei Group last year after he faced personal attacks for his political stance, which also caused controversy with China. He also resigned as chairman of Chi Mei Electronics though he remains on its board and still holds significant stakes in both companies. A close friend to former president Lee Teng-hui and a senior advisor to President Chen Shui-bian, Shi has said that disagreements with the mainland will likely lead him to move his investing to Vietnam or other Southeast Asian countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billions from beer. With two former partners from investment bank Banco Garantia, Sicupira scored big in last year’s merger between Brazilian brewer AmBev and Interbrew of the Netherlands. Sicupira was one of AmBev’s controlling shareholders. Other sources of wealth: a stake in Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas, which he ran until 1992, and profits from the sale of Banco Garantia to Credit Suisse First Boston in 1998. He holds multiple world records for underwater spearfishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out selling candles in front of a cemetery and importing used cars in the 1970s. Obtained a nationwide commercial television license in 1993 creating Polsat, today Poland’s largest private television station. Plans to float the group on the Warsaw Stock Exchange in the next year. Also has stakes in PTE pension fund and Invest Bank. Next up: working with Deutsche Telekom to gain control over Poland’s largest cellular operator.

name: Billionaires
bio: Doyenne of domesticity released from prison a few weeks ago after serving five months for obstruction of justice; never convicted on charges of insider trading. Time well served: shares of her Martha Stewart Omni-Living more than doubled during her stay. But with revenues falling and circulation of her flagship magazine, Martha Stewart Living, in decline, the convicted homemaker will have to cook up a tasty turnaround. Maybe a star turn in a new reality show will do the trick.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stokes is chairman of Australia’s Seven Network, a television and publishing conglomerate responsible for broadcasting the Olympics in Australia. Stokes owns 42.9% of Seven, which has seen its stock price rise more than 50% since September. Stokes also has his hands in an entirely different line of business: through his Australian Capital Equity he owns WesTrac, one of the larger Caterpillar industrial equipment dealers in the world, responsible for Western Australia, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. A newer part of his Caterpillar mix: a contract in northern China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall magnate crying bum rap a year after finishing nine months in prison for price-fixing as chairman of Sotheby’s. Blames colleagues for passing buck, now wishes he had testified. Survived hostile takeover bid for Taubman Centers chain, in part thanks to intervention from friendly Michigan state legislature. Mall chain now run by son, Robert, but Dad stays busy with philanthropy. Latest donation: $4 million to Lawrence Technological University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dominates several industries in Malaysia: large stakes in sole cable TV operator (Astro), the nation’s racetrack betting and lottery systems (Tanjong) and the leading mobile phone company (Maxis). All faring well recently thanks to a robust economy in part spurred by its newly elected prime minister. Krishnan reportedly paid $2.7 million for the penthouse apartment in Kuala Lumpur’s most expensive condo project, the Brinjai. (He also happens to be a director of the company that owns the project).

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, founder of Campbell Soup, inventor of condensed-soup process. Left half his fortune to son, John Jr. (d. 1989), the rest to his 3 daughters. Hope: an active donor and supporter of the St. Michael’s Country Day School in Rhode Island.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Andy” is one of the smartest-yet least-well-known-denizens of the digital world. One recent big win: He wrote Google&#39s Sergey Brin and Larry Page (see both) a $100,000 check in 1998 before they had even incorporated the company. Six years later that investment is worth $400 million, launching him into The Forbes 400. Has been a high-tech hotshot in Silicon Valley for 2 decades. Born in Germany, came to U.S. for master&#39s in electrical engineering from Carnegie Mellon University. While working toward a Ph.D. at Stanford, he invented one of the first network workstations. With help from Vinod Khosla and Scott McNealy, turned underlying programming into Sun&#39s Solaris operating system. Left to start network switch outfit Granite Systems; sold it to Cisco in 1996 for $220 million in stock. Left Cisco last December to run Kealia, a computer system design company that he sold to Sun 4 months later for $93 million in Sun stock. Now back with buddy McNealy as Sun&#39s chief architect. Also investor in chip-designing-software maker Magma Design Automation. Once lived in a big house in Woodside, Calif. with large staff; now lives alone in small Palo Alto apartment.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-sister Monika Schoeller and half-brother Dieter, inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George who founded it in 1948. Each own one-third. Took over the management of the company from Dieter in May 2001. The $2.4 billion (sales) company owns renowned German newspaper Die Zeit, publishing houses like Henry Holt in N.Y. and magazines. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining Holtzbrinck in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bored lawyer changed careers, made tech fortune with partner Mark Cuban (see), selling Broadcast.com to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in 1999. Partners going Hollywood with 2929 Entertainment: Magnolia Pictures (Capturing the Friedmans), Rysher Entertainment (Hogan's Heroes reruns and distribution rights to Sex and the City) and high-definition television network HDNet. Last year bought art house chain Landmark Theaters for undisclosed amount. Also develops nonprofit afterschool programs for inner-city children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold Sterling Software to Computer Associates in 2000 for $4 billion; fighting company ever since. Lost proxy fight to oust chairman Charles Wang and 3 board members in wake of tumbling share price. Settled for $10 million; recently filed $1 billion lawsuit over excessive executive pay; called departure of CEO Sanjay Kumar a “hallelujah day,” but company still mired in accounting scandal. Onetime refinery investor now dabbling in other things green: family has 7 Toyota Priuses, insulated his Colorado ranch with old blue jeans; director, largest stockholder of clean-energy producer Green Mountain Energy. Former chairman of Bonanza Steakhouses also holds large stake in arts-and-crafts retailer Michaels Stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout Zorlu saw a brighter future working at his family’s modest textile business in the western Anatolian town of Babadag. Smart move: what started out as bed-linen manufacturer has morphed into $8 billion (assets) umbrella encompassing 65 businesses concentrated in consumer electronics, financial services and energy. The star entrepreneur turned bankrupt TV-maker Vestel into third largest in the world over the past decade. Nonetheless, Vestel shares have lagged major Turkish indexes and could face tougher U.S. antidumping laws. Zorlu’s holding group took its DenizBank public last year, reaping at least $27 million. Shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter.
